Industrial space oversupply seen worsening

Colliers cites rules on use of space and mismatch between demand and supply

Published Thu, Jul 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] A mismatch between demand and supply of industrial space, especially in the multi-user segment, could exacerbate already rising vacancies due to imminent oversupply.

Such mismatch, according to Colliers International research and advisory director Chia Siew Chuin, stems mainly from regulatory restrictions on the use of industrial space.

"It is time that the government fine-tunes these rules," she said. The current Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) rules require users of industrial space to devote at least 60 per cent of the total floor area to core industrial activities and remainder for ancillary and secondary uses.

site_title: Mind the GAAP with tech firms
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Mind the GAAP with tech firms

Published

Thu, Jul 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

NO stock is more divisive than a tech one, it seems, where two investors can look at the same set of numbers and come to at least two different conclusions. On Tuesday, two different numbers from Twitter's second-quarter results fought for investor attention: its net loss of US$145 million based on generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP), versus its non-GAAP net income of US$14.6 million that came about when a hefty stock-based compensation expense was excluded. Non-GAAP appeared to triumph over GAAP. Twitter's share price soared 29 per cent after hours, that day.

Non-GAAP metrics are not new or uncommon, but tech firms tend to go the furthest with them. Some exclude large stock-based compensation expenses. Others exclude acquisition-related ones. The gulf between GAAP and non-GAAP realities can be significant.

One study found that 56 tech firms reported non-GAAP income that was 23 per cent higher than their GAAP earnings on average, in 2011 and 2012. Investors also tend to give non-GAAP numbers more credence than usual because of all the unknowns that loom on a tech firm's horizon. On top of that, today's tech firms have popularised non-financial metrics that have evolved into key measures.

On Tuesday, another number that excited investors was Twitter's monthly active users (MAUs) figure, which grew 24 per cent to 271 million.

The microblogging site is not the only platform whose MAUs have been made a proxy for monetisation potential. Facebook, WhatsApp and WeChat also have MAUs that are closely watched. When Twitter went public last year, it also had a metric in its filing that raised many eyebrows: "advertising revenue per 1,000 timeline views", used in lieu of the more conventional "average revenue per user" (ARPU).

This week, the former was reported matter-of-factly; ad revenue per 1,000 timeline views was up 100 per cent for the second quarter. This metric had - just nine months after causing incredulity during Twitter's listing filing - joined the ranks of the oft-cited. It might eventually follow in the footsteps of the ARPU, which has achieved informal legitimacy.

Whether an unconventional metric is accepted more for its robustness than for the mere passage of time and frequency of use, only shareholder returns will tell. There is a place for all kinds of metrics. GAAP earnings are valued because, by and large, they allow comparability between firms, but are also seen to understate earnings. Non-GAAP or non-financial measures, however, help investors take into account how two firms are different, but can be prone to abuse.

The truth, like all truths, is worth getting at, and it lies somewhere between the two approaches. But in the tech industry, where one magnate indirectly popularised the term "reality distortion field", actually arriving at the truth might take much more work.

site_title: Sentiment for services, manufacturing diverges
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Sentiment for services, manufacturing diverges

Govt surveys show services sector more optimistic about H2, manufacturing less so

Published

Thu, Jul 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Local manufacturers' business optimism has waned, while firms in the services sector have turned more upbeat, the government's latest quarterly surveys show.

But the snapshot of where Singapore companies believe business is headed in the second half of 2014, also showed clear differences within each sector. The global economic recovery bodes well for some, even as domestic labour and property-related policies are dampening the business sentiment of others.

For the services sector, a weighted 21 per cent of the 1,500 firms polled by the Department of Statistics (DoS) between June and mid-July expect business to pick up in the coming six months, up from 15 per cent of those polled in April. The proportion of pessimistic firms also dipped to 8 per cent, from 10 per cent a quarter earlier.

Taking the difference between the share of optimistic and pessimistic firms, DoS derives a measure it terms the net weighted balance. This was a positive 13 per cent for the six months ending in December, a jump from the net weighted 5 per cent that felt positive about the April to September period.

But manufacturers have become less optimistic.

The Economic Development Board's (EDB) survey of 410 manufacturing companies between June and July showed that a net weighted balance of 6 per cent are positive about the next six months - down from 7 per cent a quarter ago.

Only 9 per cent expect business to improve, down from 12 per cent of manufacturers polled in April. This offset the drop in the share of pessimistic manufacturers to 3 per cent in the latest survey, from 5 per cent in the previous poll.

The global economic recovery drove the positive outlook for some, such as the banks. A net weighted 25 per cent of those in financial and insurance services expect brighter prospects over the next six months.

Improved economic conditions in the US and Asia also underpin the higher orders forecast by machinery and systems and precision modules and components companies, EDB said. These contributed to a net weighted 11 per cent of precision engineering firms projecting better business, making precision engineering the most optimistic industrial cluster.

Similarly, better global economic conditions are expected to lift orders for manufacturers in the aerospace and land segments, while marine and offshore engineering firms are set to benefit from higher demand for oil rigs and more oil and gas-field equipment orders.

For some other business sectors though, domestic constraints trump any impact better global economic conditions may have.

Real estate was by far the most gloomy sector - a net weighted balance of 23 per cent of firms expect business to decline in the second half of 2014. Property demand continues to be dampened by policy measures levying additional stamp duties on home buyers and stricter home loan rules (the total debt servicing ratio).

Restaurants continue to struggle against a shortage of labour - in part due to tighter foreign manpower policies - resulting in a net weighted 5 per cent of food and beverage firms which are pessimistic.

For a couple of sectors, the change in sentiment was more seasonal.

Accommodation was the most optimistic services segment, with a net weighted 37 per cent of firms expecting business to improve. DoS noted that hotels tend to expect a higher business volumes in September, as the Formula One race rolls into town then.

The chemicals cluster, meanwhile, was the most pessimistic manufacturing cluster with a net weighted 3 per cent of firms expecting business to worsen. But this was largely due to plant maintenance shutdowns that the specialties segment is expecting in the second half, EDB said.

site_title: Singapore should plan for population of 10m
content:
Singapore should plan for population of 10m

Planning long term gives a better estimate of land needed: Liu Thai Ker

Published

Thu, Jul 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The Republic should plan for a population of 10 million in the long term if it is to remain sustainable as a country, says the man known widely as the architect of modern Singapore. According to Liu Thai Ker, Singapore should not stop its population growth projection at the figure of 6.9 million listed in the 2013 White Paper on Population.

"That is an interim figure and projection and obviously Singapore is going to grow beyond that," he said yesterday at a seminar, "Building a Nation: Tomorrow, Challenges and Possibilities for a Liveable Singapore".

As architect-planner and CEO of the Housing Development Board from 1969 to 1989, Mr Liu oversaw the completion of over half a million public housing units, and as CEO and chief planner of the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) from 1989 to 1992, he spearheaded the major revision of the Singapore Concept Plan and key direction for heritage conservation.

"The question is: How long do you want Singapore to exist as a sovereign state? Certainly beyond 2030, so we should plan for the longer term and for this 10 million figure as we cannot curb population growth after 2030."

Mr Liu explained that it was necessary for Singapore to plan for the longer term than for the 17 years it had planned for in the White Paper. He suggested that even though Singapore has a lot of land to be reclaimed and there is a lot of land set aside for industrial purposes that can be converted for other use, it is still better to plan for the long term so that there is a better estimate of the amount of land that is required.

"So if we need to reclaim more land from the sea, we can plan for it and do so."

Conversely, Mr Liu argued that shorter-term population planning would result in higher density as each time the population projection is made, the government may increase land density as it does not have a longer-term view of the amount of land that may be needed and that it has available. "Overall, this results in Singapore's land density increasing."

Mr Liu told BT that the 10 million figure was projected on how much Singapore could grow long term for the next 80-150 years at a population growth rate of less than one per cent each year. He said that if the growth rate were based on the upper limit of the projection of the 2013 White Paper, at 6.9 million, then Singapore could reach a population of 10 million by 2090. If however, it is based on the lower limit of 6.5 million then we may reach 10 million by 2200.

The director of RSP Architects & Engineers since 1992 and the founding chairman of the Centre for Liveable Cities said that, over time, Singapore's growth rate could contract with education, technology and productivity gains as is the case of the Scandinavian countries, which are small like Singapore, but still managed to achieve economic growth with a population growth of less than one per cent per year.

But this will take time, he added, as Singapore was not as mature as those economies and therefore still needed immigration to grow its population.

Even though he acknowledged that Singaporeans may be uncomfortable with the thought of the country ever having a population of 10 million, Mr Liu believes that it is better for the country to anticipate this and to plan for it so that the adjustment can be smoother.

"If you look at from 1960 till now, Singapore's land density has tripled but even with that, we have built a good environment through more skills and knowledge. So if we can do it then, Singaporeans should believe that we now have the ability to solve these problems and that we will have a good environment even though population density may increase."

Chew Hock Yong, CEO of the Land Transport Authority (LTA) and a panellist at the seminar, noted that while this projection of 10 million is Mr Liu's personal view, it will guarantee a critical mass for Singapore to thrive economically and in other areas. However, he admitted that there is a consideration of the human dimension and whether Singaporeans would be able to adjust to having twice the number of people and what kind of city-state they would like to live in. The seminar was organised by The Business Times in collaboration with Singapore Institute of Building Limited. It was supported by Hitachi and co-hosted by InterContinental Singapore.

site_title: Ah, the taste of Chablis and Pouilly-Fuisse
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Ah, the taste of Chablis and Pouilly-Fuisse

While both are very age-worthy budget white burgundies, the latter has the advantage of being drinkable even when young, says NK YONG

Published

Thu, Jul 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IT may seem somewhat of a downgrade to include Chablis in a discussion of budget burgundies, but Chablis is a white burgundy and the commercial reality is that top Chablis are among the best value-for-money buys in white burgundy. The top Chablis are like the top wines of the Cote d'Or; difficult to find, and quite expensive relative to other Chablis.

But leaving aside the very top ones, there are innumerable good to very fine Chablis at affordable prices. Nonetheless, among local wine lovers though, and I stress "local", it is a rare occasion to be served a Chablis at dinner!

Chablis is the northernmost appellation of Burgundy, which may explain why it tends to escape the attention of burgundy seekers. Curious to learn more about Chablis early in my Burgundy learning curve some 25 years ago, I visited Chablis and sought out a few of the top producers. Chablis is a small town, its best hotel there being Hostellerie des Clos whose restaurant we found to be quite good then - and judging from the Michelin Guide, it still is!

At the time too, there was quite a bit of discussion going on in the wine press, that Chablis producers were divided into two camps, those who used wood for ageing and those who did not. The first group consisted of only two at the time, Raveneau and Dauvissat. All the others were in the no-wood group.

I made sure I visited representative producers of both groups. Raveneau is to Chablis what Romanee Conti is to Cote d'Or. Their wines are regarded with the same awe (and the same stratospheric prices) as DRC's wines.

Chablis Grand Cru Vaudesir 1988, Joseph Drouhin

(Purchased 1992, Singapore agent Hock Tong Bee; drunk July 27, 2014.)

Medium-gold colour, surprisingly light for its age. Very fine, very lovely light aroma of citrus and nuts; bright youthful taste on the palate; a little short I thought. Lovely drink notwithstanding. What impressed was its youthfulness despite being 26 years old.

A bottle of Chablis Grand Cru Vaudesir 1986, Joseph Drouhin drunk a year ago was just as fresh. The current price of Drouhin's Chablis Vaudesir 2011 is S$123. A very modest price for a Grand Cru white burgundy from a very reputable producer.

It is not generally known that Joseph Drouhin, Louis Jadot, Joseph Faiveley and Bouchard Pere et Fils, known usually as negociants, or wine merchants, are also major vineyard owners in Burgundy. In reality, they are Negoce-Domaines.

Drouhin has extensive holdings throughout Burgundy, including Chablis in which they own parcels in most of the Grands Crus. I have happily found that Chablis from anyone of them to be true to character, and best of all, value for money. Bouchard Pere et Fils acquired ownership of one of Chablis's best known producers, William Fevre in 1998.

Chablis can taste very dry, and minerally. I have found that Chablis Premiers Crus need at least five years before becoming anywhere near drinkable. With Grands Crus, it takes at least seven years, preferably more. Both Premiers and Grands Crus benefit hugely from much longer storage, preferably 15 or more years. The problem, quite simply, is storage capacity - which could mean some investment in storage facilities!

The white burgundies from the Maconnais district, Pouilly Fuisse and Macon, are wonderful value. I like in particular the Macons (as expressed by Leflaive and Lafon). Clean pure chardonnay character, good density and freshness, very inexpensive at prices around the S$50 mark for the Macons, and not much more for the Pouilly-Fuisse.

POUILLY-FUISSE

is another white burgundy that is seldom seen, if at all. It is well worth exploring. Softer and a bit richer than Chablis, it should have better appeal than the latter.

Pouilly-Fuisse 1990, Chateau de Fuisse

(Bought from London in the early 90s, £18 per bottle. Drunk three nights ago.)

Deep yellow; fresh nutty bouquet with citrus edge, lovely wine, mature, toasty; has an edge that Bourgogne does not have. Very good. Still at peak. A very enjoyable wine, showing no signs of age.

Pouilly-Fuisse Vieilles Vignes 1983, Chateau de Fuisse

(Bought 1988, Wine Society, England £19.)

Drunk Aug 28, 2008: deep golden colour, fully mature rich bouquet, balanced, still fresh. A very intense wine, too rich for the fish course.

Just two of many examples of Pouilly-Fuisse from perhaps the best, certainly the most well-known producer, Jean-Jacques Vincent of Chateau de Fuisse. Both wines were more than 20 years old, another example of the ageing potential of these wines.

For those who find Chablis too linear, too tight and even severe, Pouilly Fuisse is a worthwhile wine to consider. The wines are bigger-bodied, softer and fruitier than Chablis. The appellation is situated at the bottom of the Maconnais, its area dominated by its landmark, the high limestone hill, Solutre, on the top of which is a very charming and quite good restaurant. This is an area which is very charming, not too far from Beaune, and producing very good inexpensive burgundies.

Another asset they have over Chablis is their drinkability even when young, although as shown by the above examples they are, like Chablis, very age-worthy.

Chateau de Fuisse

This is more or less the acknowledged top producer in Pouilly-Fuisse, its unofficial First Growth! It has been in the Vincent family since 1862.

At the time, around 1990, when I visited the property, we were warmly received by Jean-Jacques Vincent. Both the regular Pouilly Fuisse and the Vieilles Vignes bottlings are well worth taking a good look at. Both are available locally at prices well below S$100.

Regretfully, I have to confess to total ignorance of Pouilly Fuisse by other producers. Given the almost total absence of even Chateau de Fuisse's wines on the table, one can hardly expect to see any other producer's Pouilly Fuisse in Singapore, except of course those from the big negoce-domaine houses of Drouhin, Jadot, Faiveley, Louis Latour and Bouchard Pere.

More next week

Note: Chateau de Fuisse's wines can be obtained from Vinum's Caveau Chablis can taste very dry, and minerally.

site_title: Passionate about porcelain
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Passionate about porcelain

Published Thu, Jul 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

PORCELAIN is a lot more than just dainty teacups to sip from with your scones and clotted cream. You can literally trace the history of China - even the world - with it, as a new exhibition at the Asian Civilisations Museum (ACM) seeks to do.

Porcelain dates as far back as the 9th century, when it was a major source of export trade for China.

It was sold to the likes of Europe and South-east Asia, in the process documenting the cultural interactions and influences over the centuries.

Explains ACM director Alan Chong: "Porcelain was seen as something magical, special and unobtainable. It was highly prized for its decoration and the brightness of its colours. Everyone struggled to make imitations of it."

To trace the importance of porcelain and its role in history, over 180 pieces from all over the world will go on show at the ACM from tomorrow till December in China Mania! The Global Passion for Porcelain, 800- 1900.

Along with the original Chinese pieces on display are imitations made in other places like Vietnam and Europe.

"The iPhone and Samsung war is nothing compared to the 16th and 17th century," says Dr Chong. "People copied each other, trying to corner the market and dominate the trade and export. People made a lot of money from porcelain and it was a very lucrative commodity. It was for centuries something that Europe could not produce," he points out.

Dr Chong hopes that, besides allowing visitors to learn about the struggle for world porcelain dominance, the exhibition will also help them appreciate how the world has been trading for a very long time, and how economic exchanges are another way in which cultures influence one another.

In some cases, the porcelain wares made for exporting overseas have even influenced the ones made for the domestic market.

Some examples include white figurines of the Virgin Mary, which were meant for the European market. But along the way, these figurines morphed into images of Guanyin (the Chinese goddess of mercy) to cater to domestic demand.

Says Dr Chong: "This exhibition is trying to show the dynamics of the trade. It started very early, it was wider than we suspected, and there are all kinds of interesting stories about how individual cultures wanted certain kinds of things."

"The rest of the world wanted not only the physical substance (porcelain), they also wanted the Chinese decoration . . . these people didn't want to avoid China. They wanted to collect a part of it," he adds.

'China Mania! The Global Passion for Porcelain, 800-1900' runs from tomorrow to Dec 14 at the Asian Civilisations Museum. Opening hours are 10am to 7pm daily, and 10am to 9pm on Fridays. Admission is free for Singaporeans and PRs. Log on to

www.acm.org.sg

or call 6332-7798 for more information

EXHIBITION HIGHLIGHTS

INCENSE BURNER

One of the most significant pieces in the exhibition is this horse-shaped incense burner made up of multiple components from different parts of the world. Though the entire piece was assembled in Europe, the porcelain horse came from China, the red lacquer bowls from Japan, and the bronze mounts from France.

SET OF FIVE BOAR-SHAPED DISHES

Rustic-looking Chinese porcelain dishes like these were often used in meals that accompanied Japanese tea ceremonies. This particular set came from the 17th century.

BOAR'S HEAD TUREEN WITH STAND

Fancy drinking your soup out of a boar's head? Many Europeans did just that in the 18th century, with Chinese porcelain tureens shaped like geese, ducks, chickens, fish and boars.

SUBSCRIBERS

CAO reports 32% jump in Q2 profit to US$17.7m

Share of gains from associates almost triples to US$13.8m

Nisha Ramchandani

Published

Thu, Jul 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

LIFTED by higher contributions from associates, jet fuel trader China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a net profit of US$17.74 million for the second quarter, up 32.44 per cent year on year.

Revenue increased 4.35 per cent to US$3.93 billion due to higher trading volume of other oil products while earnings per share increased to 2.06 US cents, up from 1.56 US cents.

Cost of sales went up 4.45 per cent to US$3.92 billion, while gross profit slumped 22.15 per cent to US$11.17 million on the back of lower trading gains from jet fuel as a result of lower volumes and higher storage costs for fuel oil.

Operating profit was down nearly 46 per cent at US$4.76 million. Meanwhile, the share of profits from associates was US$13.79 million for the period under review, nearly tripling from US$4.99 million a year ago, on the back of higher share of profits in Pudong.

For the six months ended June 30, net profit rose 7.21 per cent to US$37.41 million, while revenue increased 5.43 per cent to US$7.96 billion.

Warning that the oil trading environment remains challenging, CAO said that it would continue to focus on its core jet supply and trading business globally while expanding its aviation marketing business into more airports outside China.

It will "also continue to expand on its diversification into trading activities in other oil products as well as seeking opportunities to invest in or acquire strategic oil assets or synergetic businesses in line with its corporate strategy to diversify its income streams".

In the stock market yesterday, the counter closed unchanged at 82.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Reflections on life, death and solitude
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Reflections on life, death and solitude

Published

Thu, Jul 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

MAYBE it was because he was alone in Berlin in the middle of a harsh winter, but when artist Michael Lee heard of an army mate who died alone at home in Singapore, that got him thinking about death and solitude.

For his exhibition at the end of the year-long residency at Kunstlerhaus Bethanien, Lee made a video "obituary" of 45 places where people have died alone, or were last seen alone. "The theme centred on solitude," he explains. He includes this video as part of his new solo exhibition at Yavuz Fine Art, titled Machine for (Living) Dying In, where the overall aim is to look into the notion of Home as well as the uncertainties surrounding its concept.

Home is as specific as the 20th place of residence he's stayed at in Singapore. Or it could be the sense of comfort one might find in less homey places, like public spaces you encounter on your travels. "Home doesn't have to be defined in a physical way," he notes.

But how does the video, with its macabre theme, mesh with the notion of Home? Lee chuckles, saying that in his view it's actually a very optimistic piece. "For a start, we need to understand why people are not comfortable or don't like to engage in the topic of death. And then there's the idea that one of the KPIs (key performance indicators) of a good life is to die with friends and relatives surrounding you on your deathbed."

What spurred this video work was news of the death of his former army mate in 2012. "He was younger than me. It was winter in Berlin when I read the report, cold and alone. In a sense, I was in a situation that could have landed me in the same predicament," he recalls.

His exhibition title was inspired by the two architects Le Corbusier and Douglas Darden, and their definitions of house and home. Le Corbusier, for example, defined a house as a "machine for living in". Darden, 70 years later, said that a house is for dying in. That morbid thought came from his unbuilt proposal for a client with chest injuries, who requested that an oxygen pump be built into the house that could be connected to his chest, so that when he died, the pump would stop.

"On the one hand, we often think of home as being safe and comfortable, but the other aspect of reality is that it's the place where we die a bit each day," muses Lee.

Focusing on space as a metaphor for physical existence and as a reflection of humanity, Lee's show is deliberately raw. He's also deviated from his usual style with a collage series titled Hazards, with a message that one is not safe anywhere, even in the sanctity of one's own home. In Slab, he rearranges everyday furniture into three-dimensional puns, such as a reference to public housing blocks. Script for an Unperformed Performance features a hammock tied across two pillars in the gallery and text that is painted on the wall describing a series of mundane activities or actions.

If it all looks very disparate, it's meant to be. After all, by creating collages, "I collect information and make connections between unrelated things - hopefully, there's some sense of reality that can be felt by the audience".

'Machine for (Living) Dying In' by Michael Lee will show at Yavuz Fine Art, 51 Waterloo Street, #03-01, from Aug 16 to Sept 21. The artist will hold a tour of the exhibition on Aug 16, from 2-4pm. For inquiries and to RSVP for the exhibition tour, please contact Irene Fung at

irene@yavuzfineart.com

or at (65) 6338-7900

site_title: Instagram's new app to debut in S'pore, NZ, South Africa
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Instagram's new app to debut in S'pore, NZ, South Africa

Published

Thu, Jul 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Instagram, the popular photo and video-sharing service acquired by Facebook for US$1 billion in 2012, has filtered out Singapore as one of only three countries to launch its new app, Bolt, which it claims is the fastest way to share content with loved ones.

Bolt, a standalone app managed by Instagram, allows users to capture and share a photo or video instantaneously with their contacts, with just one tap.

When asked if Bolt would cannibalise usage of Instagram, an Instagram spokeswoman said: "No, Bolt is a very different experience from Instagram. The latter is about capturing and sharing beautiful and powerful moments with the world; Bolt is about quickly sharing those fun and meaningful moments (that just can't wait) with people you're close to."

Content on Bolt does not stick around forever too; once users have seen a photo or video, they can literally swipe it away, and it will be deleted for good.

The app has been available for download here on Apple's App Store and Google Play since Wednesday. Users can also expect to see install ads on Instagram and Facebook, prompting them to download Bolt.

Apart from Singapore, Bolt is making its debut in New Zealand and South Africa too.

"We chose these countries as they are diverse and primarily English-speaking. While the US is, of course, our biggest market, the international market is important too - over 65 per cent of our users are outside the US," said the spokeswoman.

Instagram has chosen to start small with Bolt, so it can pay special attention to its first group of users and ensure it gets the experience in the app just right.

Daniel Chia, a Singaporean entrepreneur and founder of social networking app BlastOut, said: "I think Bolt is a great idea, because it's something like Snapchat and the new features make peer-to-peer photo messaging even more efficient. But it will be interesting to see how Bolt grows. Because its core concept is still temporal photo sharing with friends, whether you use Bolt depends on what your friends are already using."

Snapchat, a mobile app that allows users to capture and share photos or videos (known as "snaps") that self-destruct after a few seconds, is recently reported to be in talks with Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba for a financing round that would value the company at US$10 billion, according to a Bloomberg report citing anonymous sources.

BlastOut, which lets users create their own private temporary social networks around an event (where they can connect and share content anonymously with people nearby), is valued at S$2 million in venture capital terms, said Mr Chia.

For now, Bolt does not have any monetisation plans and says it is focused on building user experience first.

Likewise, Instagram launched in 2010 with no monetisation plans. But four years and an acquisition later, the unprofitable 200 million user-strong service announced that it should be ready to begin selling ads next year.

site_title: Price drop unlikely to derail longer-term property outlook
content:
Price drop unlikely to derail longer-term property outlook

Analysts see little chance of a pullback in cooling measures given liquidity

Published

Thu, Jul 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Even with a potential 10-15 per cent drop in residential prices over the next two years, the longer-term outlook for the property market remains positive. And with global interest rates set to rise only next year, there is no pressing need for the Singapore government to lift its cooling measures now, according to market watchers at the Real Estate Developers' Association of Singapore (Redas) property market update seminar.

"There is no shortage of liquidity now, which is an issue, because everyone is waiting for that 10-15 per cent decline in property prices," said Song Seng Wun, executive director and regional economist at CIMB Research, noting that a lot of liquidity in Asia is now waiting on the sidelines.

This is keeping the government from lifting its cooling measures on the property market before the US Federal Reserve raises interest rates. The Fed hike, however, may come sooner than expected given the recent positive economic data in the US, Mr Song predicted.

For now, developers will have to contend with the double whammy of falling residential prices and rising land costs as a result of a reduction of residential land supply in the second half of the Government Land Sales programme.

Also speaking at the seminar, Chua Yang Liang, head of research for South-east Asia and Singapore at JLL, noted that the government has historically intervened in periods when the property price movement deviates from economic growth by a certain margin. He is expecting the government to step in when the gap between the change in the property price index and GDP growth is wider than two percentage points and deems a 10-15 per cent price correction by 2016 "an acceptable level".

In the absence of any further government intervention, home sale volumes are likely to stay tepid and this market adjustment could be prolonged, Dr Chua said.

Residential prices started to correct only in the third quarter of 2013 after the total debt servicing ratio was introduced, as earlier cooling measures had short-lived impact on residential sales by developers.

"In this environment," said Mr Song, "unless you see a huge external shock that triggers a crisis of confidence, that triggers cashflow problems for businesses and households, the government is quite happy to keep the total debt servicing ratio in place. I don't think that is going to disappear."

"What will happen is that it may be tweaked. And how much it may be tweaked will depend on whether the economy is still generating jobs. Broadly speaking, we are seeing fundamentals still supporting the property market," he added, referring to rising wages and the full employment situation in Singapore.

Meanwhile, the office sector is holding up well with healthy business formations even though businesses are facing a tight labour market and wage inflation, property consultants at the seminar observed.

Toby Dodd, managing director at Cushman & Wakefield, said at the seminar that he expects office rents to rise in 2014 and 2015 and occupancy rates to improve on the back of tight supply of prime grade space in the next two years. He forecast that net demand would exceed 1.5 million square feet by end-2016, underpinned by economic growth and a positive business outlook. While he expressed optimism on the plan to decentralise commercial activities to regional centres outside the city centre, he stressed that it would require the right price offerings and discounts to draw tenants from the CBD to these new commercial clusters.

It sees the acquisition as a way to gain a strategic foothold in the region and complement its existing online real estate businesses in Hong Kong and China.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Mayoral mansion dresses down for new occupant

Published

Thu, Jul 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[NEW YORK] Mayor Bill de Blasio never looked comfortable amid the formal interiors and ornate staterooms of Gracie Mansion, the museum-like residence where he and his family moved this week. Century-old chandeliers and antique cabinets are not exactly in keeping with the populist de Blasio image.

So to smooth their transition into grander confines, the de Blasios turned to a decorator that better reflected their unpretentious style: West Elm.

A popular Brooklyn-based purveyor of on-trend home pieces, West Elm said on Wednesday that it had donated US$65,000 worth of furniture so New York's first family could reimagine the mansion's upstairs residential quarters.

Out: an exquisitely hand-carved, Dutch-inspired cupboard, circa 1690. In: Capiz orb pewter pendant lights, circa 2014.

The newly casual rooms feature plain, midcentury-style sofas and striped accent beanbags, and are a stark contrast with the baroque look installed by Gracie's last decorator, the celebrity designer Jamie Drake, who was paid US$7 million by former mayor Michael Bloomberg to refurbish the mansion in 2002.

The latest redesign was overseen by Mr de Blasio's wife, Chirlane McCray, who has shopped at West Elm for the family's home in Park Slope. "She really was gravitating toward the midcentury look," said Johanna Mele, a stylist at West Elm who worked with Ms McCray on the project.

Gracie Mansion, Ms Mele said, "is very heavy, ornate, and that doesn't represent the family's style at all; they've got a simpler, fresher vibe."

On a recent morning, Ms McCray and the couple's children, Chiara and Dante, took a private tour of West Elm's Chelsea showroom before it opened to the public, the company's standard practice for high-profile clients. "It was such a cool opportunity for them to come in and pick out their dream home," Ms Mele said.

Some accommodations had to be made for the mayor's 6-foot-6 frame. Sofa depth was a prized asset, and the family picked out large desk chairs for support.

Mr De Blasio and his aides are determined to be low-key about his move from the family's unadorned Park Slope rowhouse, which became a symbol of his populist campaign, to Gracie Mansion, with its Upper East Side setting and domestic staff.

Gracie décor has proved a thorny subject for its residents. Mr De Blasio's old boss, former mayor David Dinkins, faced tabloid turmoil after it emerged that the city had spent US$11,500 to handcraft a custom headboard for the mayoral bed.

The cost for the de Blasios' furniture was covered by West Elm, which earned a fair amount of product placement from the exchange. Images of the mayor's new living area were posted on the West Elm website, with commentary by the company's creative director.

Outside observers gave the design decent reviews on Wednesday, saying it was pleasing, if generic. - NYT

site_title: A waste of everybody's star wattage
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

A waste of everybody's star wattage

Dylan Tan

Published

Thu, Jul 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

OLD isn't gold as writer-director Rob Reiner achieves comedy bronze, at best, with his sweet-natured but terribly-dated senior-citizens romantic-comedy, And So It Goes. It is every bit as nonchalant as the title (named after a 1990 Billy Joel song) sounds and the lukewarm script by Mark Andrus - who also penned James L Brook's similarly-themed As Good As It Gets (1997) - could have used at least a dozen more jokes to keep things from going downhill fast.

All this despite enjoyable performances from old-timers Michael Douglas and Diane Keaton; possibly the only two reasons to catch this. The former lets loose as a grumpy old man who appears hard on the outside but is, as you've guessed it, soft as marshmallow on the inside.

In one of the film's most ludicrous scenario, this bad-a** actually helps a neighbour whom he's more used to squabbling with, deliver her baby. (It's not Douglas' fault for choosing to be in this movie; it's his agent's and Andrus'.)

Keaton's character might go down a little easier with the audience though she's often guilty of playing it a little too cute for someone her age; that's something perhaps best left to child star Sterling Jerins - from TV's Deception and last seen on the big screen as Brad Pitt's daughter in the zombie apocalypse thriller World War Z - who plays Douglas' granddaughter.

Good thing Keaton adds a charming comic edge to character - that of a jazz singer who can get a little emotionally overwhelmed by the sad lyrics of the songs she croons - so the cringe factor is kept to a bare minimum.

As an on-screen couple, the Douglas-Keaton pairing lights up the screen and they have an easy chemistry with each other despite Andrus' tired script introducing the romance between them very late in the film. Too much time instead is spent on building Oren (Douglas) into the guy you want to hate by making him an all-round meanie who seems to have a bad day in the office ... everyday.

There is, of course, a "good" reason behind all this behaviour - Oren has lost his zest for life after years of caring for and then eventually watching his wife pass away. For closure, the real estate agent has one final deal on his hands which he'd like to see through personally - to sell his own family home.

Things get a little more complicated when his estranged ex-junkie son, Luke (Scott Shepherd), shows up to drop off his daughter, Sarah (Jerins) with her grandfather before he starts his prison sentence. Oren doesn't know any better what to do with her so he leaves things to his neighbour, Leah (Keaton) to care for the little girl.

It gets predictable from here, and before the film's brief-but-strangely-draggy 94-minute running time is up, Leah brings out the good in Oren while he also teaches her a lesson or two in building her self-esteem.

Reiner directs with heart and his lead actors display plenty of it even with the lacklustre plot in their hands.

And So It Goes might work as a nice little made-for-television movie but on the big screen, it comes across as a missed opportunity and a waste of everybody's star wattage.

Rating:

C

News of tie-up sends CEFC shares up

JV with Rizhao Port Group unit will build and run Rizhao port oil storage facilities

Published

Thu, Jul 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

PETROCHEMICAL and fuel oil trader CEFC International's shares gained 0.5 cent, or 15 per cent, to 3.8 Singapore cents yesterday after it announced in the morning that it had tied up with a subsidiary of state-owned company Rizhao Port Group (RPG) to build and operate oil storage facilities in Rizhao port in China.

The joint venture (JV) between CEFC's wholly owned subsidiary Hong Kong CEFC Petrochemical and Energy Pte Ltd, and Rizhao Port Oil Terminal will have an initial registered capital of 350 million yuan (S$70.5 million), with CEFC Hong Kong subscribing to a 49 per cent stake for 171.5 million yuan in cash.

Rizhao Port Oil Terminal will satisfy the consideration for its 51 per cent stake by transferring to the JV company the land on which the facilities will be constructed, and contribute the balance amount in cash if the value of the land is less than 178.5 million yuan

The project will cost some 700 million yuan, including land costs and construction and development of the oil storage facilities. The remaining 350 million yuan of the project cost will be funded by bank borrowings.

Said CEFC CEO Zang Jian Jun: "The entry into the oil storage business is a major milestone for CEFC. We view this synergistic partnership with RPG as an extension of our turnaround story, where we have successfully restructured CEFC's business by moving from the previous loss-making beauty product business to a new strategic focus in the more profitable oil trading business."

RPG and its subsidiaries are involved in port management businesses in China, including port loading and unloading and cargo warehousing for bulk cargo such as coal, cement and steel. Rizhao Port Oil Terminal owns and operates the existing infrastructure of Rizhao port, and also runs the existing 750,000 cubic metre crude oil and fuel oil storage facilities in the port area.

CEFC, formerly known as Sun East Group Ltd, suffered consecutive years of financial losses in the beauty product business. It entered the petrochemical and fuel oil trading business in late 2012, and the relative success of the new business led to its exit from the exchange's watchlist on Aug 7 last year.

The group expects to be able to leverage its inventory of oil and petrochemical products stored at the new facilities upon its completion in two years, which will increase its trade volume and margins. Surplus capacity may also be leased to third parties to generate more revenue and cross-selling opportunities for the group, it said.

"Our strategy is to take on a multi-pronged approach to expand vertically and horizontally along the petroleum and petrochemical distribution value chain," said Mr Zang. "We are excited about this greenfield investment in Rizhao port, which is China's ninth largest and Shandong's second biggest port with rapid growth potential. This collaboration with state-owned RPG is expected to raise the group's profile as well as pave the way for future collaboration opportunities."

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

India's Bengaluru posts record home sales

Published Thu, Jul 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Home sales in Bengaluru, India's information technology hub, rose to a record in the June quarter as new projects boosted demand, according to Liases Foras Real Estate Rating & Research Pvt.

Sales in the city, home to the Indian units of Intel Corp and Google Inc, rose 10 per cent to 17.77 million square feet in the three months ended June 30 from the previous quarter, said Pankaj Kapoor, the founder of Liases Foras, a Mumbai-based real estate research company. "Sales in Bengaluru have been the highest among the six major cities," Mr Kapoor said, citing others it tracks, which are Mumbai, Chennai, Hyderabad, National Capital Region and Pune.

The pick-up in India's off-shoring business is driving demand for homes in the southern city formerly known as Bangalore. Demand for Grade-A offices will climb 3 per cent to 22.9 million sq ft this year from last year, the first increase in three years and the strongest demand to be seen in Bengaluru, according to broker Cushman & Wakefield Inc. Sales in the city were boosted by projects that were marketed by Godrej Properties Ltd and Puravankara Projects Ltd, Mr Kapoor said.

Londoners cashing out, selling houses in city

In October, he was offered £1,000 (US$2,100) per square foot for his London townhouse. Other homes in the area were going for about 30 per cent less. Mr Adamson accepted it immediately.

London's housing market, having outperformed the rest of the UK with price gains of more than 50 per cent in five years, is cooling as owners such as Mr Adamson cash out. They're leaving the city for less costly suburban and country homes because they expect mortgage rates to rise and new lending rules to damp prices. London estate agents had the largest increase in instructions to sell homes in Britain in June and the biggest drop in people seeking to buy them, according to the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (Rics).

site_title: Art comes alive in interactive experience
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Art comes alive in interactive experience

Installations from 11 Asian artists will explore nine different senses to fully engage audience, reports RACHEL LOI

Published

Thu, Jul 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

AS kids, we learn about the five senses - sight, smell, taste, touch and hearing. But in recent years, science has added more to the list - the ability to detect movement and position, balance, time, and pain.

The Singapore Art Museum's (SAM) latest exhibition, Sensorium 360: Contemporary Art and the Sensed World, explores these important components of the human body that keep us alive and allow us to experience life.

"Our senses are so integral to the way we navigate the world," says SAM's curator Joyce Toh. "We want people to have a renewed awareness and appreciation for our senses, and how they work with the mind. They're so vital for us to get through the world and yet we often take them for granted because we simply expect our senses to work," she adds.

Sensorium 360 will showcase the works of 11 artists from Singapore and Asia - including Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia, the Philippines, and China. Their works are contemporary art installations that explore nine different senses by interacting with the audience in creative ways.

Explains SAM director Susie Lingham: "You think you can close your eyes and then you don't see art, but this time around you close your eyes and you'll see nothing, but the art is still there. And it will invade your senses without you intending it because you will be hearing it and smelling it."

For example, Filipino artist Christina Poblador's work titled May Puno sa Dibdib ng Kamatayan (There is a tree in the heart of death) is an installation where she has paired a range of different smells to a selection of musical compositions that are significant to her. You're supposed to put on a pair of headphones and listen to the music, while sniffing an arrangement of 10 test tubes that correspond to each piece of music. Through this, the artist wants to examine the relationship between the sense of smell and hearing, especially since both are effective at evoking nostalgia.

While you are encouraged to interact with the artworks in this exhibition, it's not all without a purpose, says Ms Toh. "This will be an engaging show, but it's not just entertainment. There are a lot of rich concepts and so much about the human condition can be learned by looking at the mind and body in tandem and how they work in mysterious ways."

Some of the works discuss more serious issues like CCTV surveillance or seeing the world through the eyes of visually-impaired people. But ultimately, it all starts with just experiencing the works, says Ms Toh. "Sometimes, talking about the work diminishes some of the enjoyment because it makes it too explained," she says. "Yes, there's a lot of thinking behind it, but first and foremost is the experience of the artwork itself."

rachloi@sph.com.sg

@RachelLoiBT

'Sensorium 360: Contemporary Art and the Sensed World' runs at the Singapore Art Museum till Oct 22. Opening hours are from 10am to 7pm daily, and 10am to 9pm on Fridays. Admission is free for Singaporeans and PRs. Log on to

www.singaporeartmuseum.sg

or call 6589 9580 for more information

CAGE

Chinese artist Li Hui's installation uses laser beams to create two virtual cages in a dark room. Although the lasers do not actually hurt, they tend to affect people psychologically and make them feel trapped. On a philosophical level, the work also acts as a metaphor for the imaginary boundaries people create for themselves, which might not actually affect them in reality.

UNSEEN

Local artist Alecia Neo's installation began in 2012 during a residency in Taiwan. There, she worked with six visually-impaired people and gave each of them a 35 mm disposable camera to take photos of the world from their perspective. From those photos, she created tactile prints, or "braille drawings" that line the perimeter of a dimly-lit room so audiences can "see" these photographs by touching them.

THE OVERVIEW

INSTALLATION

This work by local artist Eugene Soh invites members of the public to put on a pair of goggles to navigate a maze painted on the floor. The goggles replace the participant's normal view, so they see themselves going through the maze from a different perspective such as a "god-view" from above, or with lateral vision like that of a chameleon, among others.

site_title: UOB's Q2 profit beats forecast
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

UOB's Q2 profit beats forecast

Better results on the back of higher net interest income, investment gains

Published

Thu, Jul 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

UNITED Overseas Bank yesterday posted better than expected second-quarter net profit of S$808 million, up 3.2 per cent from a year ago on the back of higher net interest income and investment gains.

The earnings were 2.5 per cent higher than those for Q1 2014.

The result was above the S$764 million mean estimate of seven analysts polled by Reuters.

Annualised earnings per share rose to S$1.97, from S$1.96 for Q2 2013 and S$1.94 for Q1 2014.

UOB declared an interim dividend of 20 Singapore cents, unchanged from a year ago.

Net interest income increased 10.7 per cent from Q2 2013 to S$1.12 billion, contributed by loans growth.

Customer loans rose 11.7 per cent year-on-year and 2.4 per cent over the preceding quarter to S$193 billion as at June 30. The steady loan growth was broad-based across territories and industries.

UOB chief executive Wee Ee Cheong said that the global economy is more stable than six months ago and the region is benefiting from that.

"Six months ago, markets were concerned about QE (quantitative easing) tapering and the impact on Asia," said Mr Wee at the results briefing.

UOB saw that as positive as it meant that the US economy was recovering, he said.

Loans growth for the full year will be a high single digit, he said.

The bank's net interest margin remained unchanged at 1.71 per cent in Q2 2014.

The net interest margin is expected to be maintained for the rest of the year, as the group has to balance funding costs, said Lee Wai Fai, UOB chief financial officer.

Banks have been competing fiercely for deposits in Singapore which have not kept pace with loans growth.

Deposits in June rebounded after a contraction in April and May, official data show. The loan-to-deposit ratio (LDR) stayed flat at 110.6 per cent in June, but was still a record high since 1998.

Deposits were up by 0.8 per cent month-on-month (m-o-m) in June, mainly led by ACU or US dollar deposits, up 2.6 per cent m-o-m. Domestic banking units deposits, or SGD deposits contracted for the third consecutive month, and were down 0.3 per cent m-o-m.

UOB has also been diversifying its funding sources. The bank increased its US commercial paper programme limit from US$10 billion to US$15 billion and raised more than S$12 billion of short-term funds as at end-June.

UOB said that customer deposits at end June was S$216 billion, up 8.5 per cent from a year ago across a broad base of current and savings accounts and fixed deposits. Its LDR at end June was 87.8 per cent, up from 85.3 per cent a year ago.

Non-interest income grew 21.1 per cent from Q2 2013 to S$760 million with increased gains from investment securities. This was offset by a fall in fee and commission income, down 6 per cent at S$410 million due to lower wealth management, fund management and loan-related fees.

Costs increased 8.4 per cent over Q2 2013 to S$787 million on higher staff and revenue-related expenses. Expense-to-income ratio improved, recording 41.7 per cent in Q2 2014 compared to 44.2 per cent in Q2 2013.

UOB shares closed trading yesterday at S$24.16, up 11 Singapore cents.

OSIM Q2 profit rises 13% to S$29.5m

Published

Thu, Jul 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

OSIM International's second-quarter net profit rose 13 per cent year-on-year to a record S$29.53 million.

It proposed a second interim dividend of two Singapore cents per share, payable on Oct 2.

The group yesterday said: "We are pleased with the record performance. We launched uDiva massage sofa during the quarter which has created lots of awareness and good response. We expect uDiva to continue to do well for the current year."

Revenue for the three months ended June 30 increased 10 per cent to S$182.66 million, driven by higher consumer demand for its OSIM products, nutritional supplements and luxury tea. Additionally, TWG Tea, which became a subsidiary in October last year, contributed to OSIM's sales.

OSIM, which operates in 30 countries around the world, said that all regions contributed to better sales growth for the quarter, with North Asia contributing the highest revenue of S$101 million, or 55 per cent of its sales.

Earnings per share for the reporting quarter were 3.87 Singapore cents, an increase from 3.61 Singapore cents a year ago.

For the six months to end-June, net profit rose 13.9 per cent year on year to S$58.38 million, backed by 12.39 per cent increase in revenue to S$355.28 million.

OSIM expects its business to remain strong for the rest of the year and is looking to open new OSIM and TWG Tea outlets, while growing sales through new products at its GNC/Richlife outlets.

OSIM targets to have 45 TWG outlets by the end of the year, with plans to open new ones at Taipei 101, Shanghai Grand Gateway & IAPM and Guangzhou Tai Koo Hui in the coming quarter. There are 33 TWG Tea outlets now.

Additionally, OSIM is targeting to add 20 to 30 OSIM outlets to its existing stable of 578 outlets, and close underperforming outlets.

"We regularly review performance of our outlets and there were selected closures of non-performing outlets," it said.

However, it notes that sales per OSIM outlet have increased.

OSIM shares closed half a cent higher at S$2.87 yesterday.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Experiencing poetry in action

Published

Thu, Jul 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

CLOUD MESSENGER

IN Kalidasa's original lyric poem Meghaduta, a yaksa (nature spirit) pining for his wife persuades a passing cloud to help him send her a love message. The cloud agrees to do so, only after the yaksa describes in detail all the astonishing sights and wonders the cloud would see on its way to his wife's home.

This 1,500-year-old story has, in the hands of Haresh Sharma and Alvin Tan, transformed into a contemporary play about the experiences of seven graduating students of the Intercultural Theatre Institute (ITI).

Most of them are foreigners who've spent three years away from home to pursue the ITI theatre course, so the ancient tale resonates with them.

Called Cloud Messenger, the play has three concurrent storylines: the first involves the students talking about their experiences of being in Singapore and how they stay in touch with their loved ones; the second has the students playing foreign workers (a maid, a security guard and a cleaner) who also experience estrangement coming here for work; and the third is a fable about young clouds who have to come to the cloud academy to train to become cloud messengers - just like the one in Kalidasa's story.

Sharma and Tan were invited by the school to work with the graduating class, and the play was created after numerous workshops with them.

Tan raves: "The students are so disciplined and committed. We'd tell them what we're trying to achieve in a scene, and they'd discuss among themselves and come up with ideas. It's a joy working with them."

'Cloud Messenger' is playing at Drama Centre Black Box on Aug 8 and 9. Tickets at S$25 from

Around Town

Published

Thu, Jul 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Pick of the week

The Boys in the Band:

Mart Crowley's thought-provoking The Boys in the Band takes to the Singapore stage as a follow-up to the critically acclaimed Take Me Out.

It's the second of Tim Garner Productions' series of lesbian, gay, bi-sexual, transgender-themed plays which aims to create a platform of discussion about diversity, equality and inclusion in Singapore.

The famous 1969 off-Broadway play, which depicted gay men onstage in a serious light and started the gay rights movement in United States, premieres in Singapore, featuring an all-male, multi-national cast.

Set in Upper East Side of Manhattan, New York City, in 1968, the play follows a varied group of men as they celebrate a friend's 32nd birthday. However, the atmosphere quickly changes from cheerful to tense as the characters become intoxicated, and prejudices are laid bare and inner personalities are revealed, causing the audience to ponder over the notion of friendship - both the character's and the audience's own. When the group decides to play a game that requires each character to make a confession, the result will shock and intrigue the audience.

The play also discusses social issues like monogamy and status. It stars actors like Chris Bucko, Nelson Clemente and Tim Garner and Robert Jenkin.

'The Boys in the Band' runs from Aug 7 to Aug 16 at the Alliance Francaise Theatre. The show is held at 8pm on Mondays, Wednesdays to Fridays and Sundays, and 2pm and 8pm on Saturdays. Tickets cost S$45, S$55, S$65 and S$70. To purchase tickets, log on to

The Istana Art Event is back, with plenty of family-themed programmes on the itinerary. Held in conjunction with the Istana Open House, the event offers participants a series of activities presented by a range of museums and institutions at the Arts and Heritage Village. Interactive art and play installations, by local artists and designers, will also be available for visitors to enjoy.

Well-received art competition On-the-Spot will be held, and kids aged three to 12 are welcome to take part. The first 1,000 participants to submit their work will receive a free Istana Art Event goodie bag. Guests are also invited to pen their wishes for Singapore on wish cards and hang them onto the Wish House installation.

'Istana Art Event' will be held tomorrow at the Istana Grounds. The event runs from 8am to 5pm. Admission is free

>Dining

Celebrity Chef Dine Around:

Fancy having dinner for a good cause? You can at Celebrity Chef Dine Around. Taking place at Marina Bay Sands, guests will enjoy a fabulous dinner with award-winning cuisine including signature dishes from CUT by Wolfgang Puck (Pork Belly Sandwich, Shrimp "Cocktail"), Osteria and Pizzeria Mozza (Cauliflower Fritti and Ricotta Bruschetta) and db Bistro Moderne (Spicy Tuna Tartare and House-made Foie Gras Terrine).

The project acts not only as an initiative to encourage community building, but also as encouragement to budding entrepreneurs and local talents in showing their creativity through their services and products. Vendors at the market will offer a range of goods from cold-pressed juices and smoothies and green produce to Asian-flavoured handmade gourmet nuggets and more. The event will be held every first Sunday of each month.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Aussie project go-ahead a revenue boost for Linc

Value of royalty contract will also surge, it says

Published

Thu, Jul 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE Australian government's approval for the development of the Carmichael coal mine in Queensland would generate about A$133 million (S$154.1 million) a year in revenue for mainboard-listed Linc Energy, as it owns royalty over the coal that is mined and transported.

Not only that, the value of the royalty contract - which can be traded - will also "increase considerably", said its CEO Peter Bond in a news release yesterday.

Linc Energy sold the underlying coal asset to Indian conglomerate Adani Group in August 2010, and holds an inflation-indexed royalty contract that provides for A$2 for each tonne of coal produced from the Carmichael coal mine for the first 20 years of production.

The proposed development of what is expected to be the largest coal mine in Australia, has got environmentalists up in arms as they say it would threaten the Great Barrier Reef.

Australia's environment minister Greg Hunt, in giving approval for the coal mine and an accompanying rail project in Queensland on Monday, said that the development was subjected to 36 conditions.

The mine is forecast to produce 60 million tonnes of thermal coal a year at its peak. Linc Energy arrived at the A$133 million figure in royalty revenue based on this.

The mine, which by some estimates will provide fuel to generate electricity for up to 100 million people in India, is expected to contribute about A$3 billion to the Queensland economy each year at full capacity, and generate thousands of jobs.

All coal will be transported through a privately-owned railway that Adani will build with South Korean firm Posco E&C, which connects to the existing Aurizon rail infrastructure near Moranbah, and shipped through coal terminal facilities at the Port of Abbot Point and/or the Port of Hay Point.

"From a personal viewpoint, it was Linc Energy that explored the area and discovered this great coal resource, so every Linc Energy shareholder should be proud of the fact that this significant project exists because of the entrepreneurial endeavours of our team and our company," said Mr Bond. "We look forward to watching the Carmichael project develop into Australia's largest coal mining operation."

The counter closed 0.5 cent lower at S$1.25 yesterday.

Crowdfunding goes specialist

Crowdfunding has been around for a couple of years now but it has evolved into niche platforms in recent times. RACHEL LOI speaks to some of these new entrants to find out how they stand out from the crowd and what customised services they offer

Published Thu, Jul 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

WHEN it first started, crowdfunding was a simple idea - people with ideas but no start-up capital would turn to the Internet to raise money. It also marked the launch of pioneer sites like Kickstarter and Indiegogo, which created a dedicated space for creatives to put their ideas out and await interested supporters.

Now, the industry has evolved to spawn a new generation of crowdfunding platforms - those which provide customised services catered to niche industries.

In Singapore, Haystakt was the first one out of the stable in 2012. Unlike most crowdfunding platforms which cater to project ideas from any genre, Haystakt zeroes in on the creative market. Designers of furniture, for example, can make a campaign page with a target number of pre-orders for a chair, and only start production once they hit their target.

site_title: Labour market still tight in Q2, layoffs down
content:
Labour market still tight in Q2, layoffs down

But loss of 2,600 manufacturing jobs highest since Q3 '09

Lee U-Wen

Published

Thu, Jul 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] The labour market remained tight in the second quarter of 2014 as unemployment rates held firm and the number of retrenchments came down.

According to preliminary estimates released by the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) yesterday, the overall seasonally adjusted unemployment rate stayed at 2 per cent in June.

This is a rate that economists and analysts say is largely in line with their market expectations, and has remained fairly constant for the last four quarters.

The seasonally adjusted unemployment rates for citizens remained at 3 per cent, while the resident unemployment rate improved slightly to 2.8 per cent, compared to 2.9 per cent in March.

The report, released by the ministry's Manpower Research and Statistics Department, also showed that job creation fell in the April-June period.

There were 22,000 jobs created in the second quarter, down 22 per cent from the previous quarter's 28,300. The total employment growth a year ago was 33,700.

Citigroup economist Kit Wei Zheng noted that the second-quarter drop in job creation contrasted with the average increase of 16.5 per cent quarter-on- quarter in the past two years.

This, he added, was a possible reflection of the cyclical slowdown in economic activity seen in the first half of 2014.

Femke Hellemons, country manager of human resource firm Adecco Singapore, felt that the slower job creation was due to the impact of sunset industries and sunset jobs, where certain jobs were made redundant or replaced by technology.

In all, the MOM report found that Singapore's total employment stood at 3.54 million in June, 3.6 per cent higher than a year ago.

Services continued to generate the majority of employment gains with 20,100 jobs, although this was lower than the 24,900 figure in the first quarter.

The news wasn't as good for the manufacturing sector, however. The industry shed some 2,600 workers - a sharp contrast from the growth of 2,300 workers a year ago - and also marks the largest quarterly fall in manufacturing jobs since the third quarter of 2009.

Growth in the construction sector, meanwhile, slowed to 4,300, almost half the 8,500 jobs created in June last year.

"With the exception of manufacturing, the low unemployment rate suggests that it may have been supply constraints that led to lower job creation," said Citigroup's Mr Kit.

As far as layoffs are concerned, MOM found that redundancies declined across all the major sectors.

About 2,300 workers were released in the second quarter, down from the 3,110 who were let go in the previous three months and the 3,080 laid off in June 2013.

Services formed the bulk of the retrenchments with 1,500 people affected, followed by manufacturing (500) and construction (300).

Kelvin Wong, chief technical strategist at City Index Asia, reckons that job creation in the coming months in Singapore should show signs of improvement.

This is provided the key economic data of Singapore's major trading partners - such as the United States employment payrolls and China manufacturing data - continue to stabilise and surprise on the upside.

Commenting on the tight labour market, Ms Hellemons of Adecco said that companies were facing challenges with the ongoing labour crunch here.

While the lower number of layoffs could point towards a continued optimistic economic outlook, she said that it could also mean that companies were being more cautious in releasing employees due to the limited talent pool in some areas.

While the tight labour market was proving to be a strain on companies in terms of hiring, one silver lining is that younger workers could benefit as a result.

"It does provide interesting opportunities for young job seekers who can observe trends in the job market and specifically skill and train for a career in areas where there may not be an abundance of available talent," said Ms Hellemons.

"We have seen this take place in the hospitality sector, which has created an additional number of job openings over the past few years," she added.

The full MOM report is available at

http://stats.mom.gov.sg

. The ministry said it would release more comprehensive labour market data for the second quarter on Sept 15.

site_title: MH370 survey ships making progress
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

MH370 survey ships making progress

Published Thu, Jul 31, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SYDNEY] Two ships surveying the sea floor where Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 is thought to have crashed are making steady progress with a deepwater search to get underway in September, Australian authorities said yesterday.

Since May, experts have been surveying an area of about 60,000 square kilometres along the seventh arc - a thin but long line that includes all possible points where the last known communication between the aircraft and a satellite could have taken place.

It is using two vessels - Chinese survey ship Zhu Kezhen and the Australian- contracted Fugro Equator - to map the ocean floor in the remote region, a process considered crucial to identify possible hazards that could affect the deepwater search.

The Joint Agency Coordination Centre (JACC) said that by Wednesday, the Zhu Kezhen had sounded over 25,000 sq km while the Fugro Equator had surveyed more than 43,000 sq km.

A third vessel, Malaysia's KD Mutiara, will join them in August.

"The bathymetric survey work is expected to be completed by September," JACC said in a statement. "The deepwater search is expected to commence in September following the appointment of a prime contractor through a request for tender process."

Australia is leading the multinational hunt for the plane which vanished on March 8 with 239 people on board.

It is believed to have crashed in the southern Indian Ocean but despite an extensive air, sea surface and underwater search, no trace has been found.

Australian officials have said MH370 was almost certainly on autopilot when it ran out of fuel and crashed, with the crew likely "unresponsive" due to a lack of oxygen.

Australia has been keen to make clear that the mission to find the plane was continuing uninterrupted, even as the head of the search coordination agency, Angus Houston, was sent to Ukraine to help with the recovery effort following the tragic downing of MAS Flight MH17. - AFP

Revenue rose 4.2 per cent to US$341 million, with its hotels in Bangkok impacted by the ongoing political uncertainty, and weaker performances in Jakarta and Manila. Terratech flat after strong start

Closing of 23.5 Singapore cents is 2.2% above IPO price

Published

Wed, Jul 30, 2014 · 10:00 PM

THE stock of premium marble producer Terratech Group shot up by more than a fifth to a high of 28 Singapore cents on its first day of trading on the Catalist board yesterday.

But the initial burst of interest which saw the stock open trading at 27 Singapore cents evaporated, resulting in it closing the day at 23.5 Singapore cents, just 2.2 per cent above its initial public offering price of 23 cents. More than 111.5 million shares changed hands.

Terratech, a unit of Singapore Exchange-listed engineering firm Tritech Group, had issued 108.7 million shares - comprising 43.5 million new shares and 65.2 million vendor shares - with the offer price giving it a value of about S$141.46 million.

Terratech operates at the Kelantan Marble Quarry in Malaysia, consisting of four hills with an extraction area of up to 25.94 ha, and has an order book of about S$23.46 million to date.

It counts the decorative building materials industry in China as among the world's major consumers of marble.

Based on development trends projected by the Chinese government, Terratech said consumption of marble in China is expected to register a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 17.6 per cent between 2010 and 2015.

Terratech hopes to use the net IPO proceeds of about S$7 million to expand production capacity and processing facilities, and for working capital.

Its CEO, Loh Chang Kaan, said the firm was honoured to be the first marble producer listed on the Catalist board.

"As a listed company, it provides us with a platform to accelerate our commercial production, and helps to boost our profile and raise awareness among our potential customer base," he said. "In the near future, we plan to venture into the calcium carbonate powder production business and may explore strategic acquisitions of additional stone quarries."

Terratech's listing brings the total number of SGX-listed mineral, oil and gas companies - a sector the exchange has been actively courting - to 22, with total market capitalisation of S$5.5 billion.

Meanwhile, Tritech's shares ended trading at 23.5 Singapore cents yesterday, down 11.3 per cent.

site_title: Chinese investors on global real estate buying spree
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Chinese investors on global real estate buying spree

H1 overseas property investments up 17%, 84% jump for homes

Published

Wed, Jul 30, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[HONG KONG] China's institutional investment in property overseas rose 17 per cent in the first six months of this year, with residential investment surging 84 per cent, real estate services firm Jones Lang LaSalle (JLL) said yesterday.

The gains come as Chinese investors pursue opportunities outside their home turf, where the outlook for the real estate sector is overshadowed by issues such as tight financing and high inventories which are weighing on prices.

London was the most popular destination for Chinese institutional investors, with a total of US$2.3 billion, as efforts by the city to draw Chinese capital into major infrastructure projects spilled into residential and commercial markets, JLL said.

San Francisco and Chicago followed with US$548 million and US$365 million, respectively.

Sydney was fourth, followed by Madrid, after China's largest commercial developer Dalian Wanda bought a historic skyscraper in Spain's capital city from the nation's largest bank, Santander, for US$361 million.

"For first-time overseas investors it makes sense to target the most liquid cities. But, for the more experienced, looking at smaller less liquid markets like Spain where yields are higher but so are the risks, it is a natural progression," David Green-Morgan, JLL's global capital markets research director said.

Chinese real estate outbound investment totalled US$5.4 billion during the period, with commercial investment contributing US$4 billion.

JLL noted that developers and insurance companies remained the most active investors, and while the interests mainly focused in core office and mixed use development projects in global gateway cities, there was an increasing interest for hotel and hospitality products in popular Chinese tourist destinations.

The introduction of the Golden Visa in many southern European counties has also raised the profile of these locations among Chinese mainland investors, it added.

Separately, on retail investments, the United States was the country most favoured by Chinese home buyers, according to Juwai.com, the largest real estate portal that targets Chinese buyers looking abroad, based on inquiry data from first-half 2014.

Australia ranked second and Canada third, even though it cancelled the Immigrant Investor Programme in February. The UK was fourth.

"We have not seen any measurable impact on Chinese demand for property in Canada as a result of the ending of the investment visa programme," Juwai.com's co-chief executive officer Andrew Taylor told Reuters. - Reuters

Far East Group seeks M&A deals

Published Wed, Jul 30, 2014 · 10:00 PM

REFRIGERATION and cooling systems provider Far East Group has plans to expand its business in China and South east-Asia and is looking out for merger and acquisition opportunities, according to chief executive officer Steven Loh.

Far East Group manufactures and distributes heating, ventilation, air-conditioning and refrigeration products for various sectors including the retail, food processing and pharmaceuticals industries. China's increasing urban affluence has raised demand for cooling solutions in homes, offices and logistics. Mr Loh said the market is very large and offers high potential for growth as compared to South-east Asia, which is growing "organically".

Far East Group completed the acquisition of Eden Refrigeration Manufacturing located in Jiangsu, China, in July 2013. The group currently has two manufacturing plants there and plans to increase utilisation of the 32,000 sq m site over the next three years. A new R&D centre is also slated for completion at the facility by 2016.

It also plans to tap into China's market potential by targeting its "middle-high segment" via new contractor partnerships and value-added consultancy services for clients.

In terms of distribution, the group is discussing possible collaborations or acquisitions of companies with existing distribution networks in China.

Far East Group also plans to widen its distribution network in South-east Asia. It currently has a presence in Singapore, Malaysia and Hong Kong, in addition to two subsidiaries in Vietnam acquired earlier this month. The group is also looking at possible opportunities in Myanmar and Cambodia, said Mr Loh.

Far East Group's shares closed at S$0.192 cents yesterday, up one cent from the previous day.
