site_title: IoT's success will hinge on data centres
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

IoT's success will hinge on data centres

Powerful computers and big data analytics needed to crunch data from connected devices

Published Sun, Jul 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IF YOU have a connected home, you could at any moment, no matter where you are in the world, pull out your smartphone and adjust the air temperature in your living room, or the water temperature in your bathroom. If you are a fitness buff, with a connected wristband, you can keep track of your activity level, watch your progress over time and compare your performance with others.

But this, the experts say, is only the tip of the iceberg. If this year's consumer technology events are any indication, the Internet of Things (IoT) and wearable computing are about to go mainstream in a big way.

These new technologies won't just make our daily lives more convenient and homes more automated, they will change the way we work as well. The Asia-Pacific market for IoT could be worth as much as US$100 billion over the next few years, depending on which analyst report you view.

So what does this all mean for the data centre landscape? All that data will need somewhere to go. According to Cisco, there will be upwards of 50 billion connected devices worldwide by 2020. All these devices will generate huge amounts of data which will end up in, or passing through, data centres.

IoT data won't purely be the concern of companies that provide IoT products and services or their ecosystem of partners and suppliers - it will affect every government or private organisation that adopts IoT or machine-to-machine or wearable technologies to improve operations.

In a report published recently, analyst firm IDC expects IoT technology and services revenue worldwide to grow from US$4.8 trillion in 2012 to US$7.3 trillion by 2017. The report notes that the greatest opportunity will initially be in the consumer, discrete manufacturing and government vertical industries.

The same trends are expected to be mirrored in Asia, with smart cities, intelligent utilities, metros, homes and cars, as well as wearable devices all contributing to the mix. But many verticals will see growing adoption of IoT. Organisations will thus need to think carefully about how they will manage and where they will put all of this valuable data.

Data security will be a primary concern as connected devices proliferate. Certain types of data or devices will be relatively innocuous, such as the egg carton that tells you when you're out of eggs. After all, how much damage could scammers really do if they accessed that data or hacked the egg carton? But the damage done if hackers accessed other types of IoT devices or data could be quite significant.

I suspect that many enterprises will be more comfortable keeping their own IoT data safely tucked away within their own data centre or private cloud, but in other cases, putting it on the public cloud will be perfectly suitable.

As more of the physical world is connected, any down time will also create more frustration, or worse. Think about how frustrated we all get when email or even Twitter is down briefly. But when an M2M (machine to machine) system in a manufacturing plant goes down temporarily, or cash withdrawals are affected at an ATM overseas, the productivity loss could be more acute.

A significant amount of the value of connected devices will come from analysing all the data these devices produce. This will drive the need for powerful computers and big data analytics to crunch the data the devices spew out. These systems will require space, power, cooling and connectivity to get the job done.

IoT data will be highly dynamic, too. The continuous flow of data will often be shared with an ecosystem of partners or packaged with content to deliver different types of services. Or it will be combined with other data to create new insights. As such, the need for direct and secure access to partners and suppliers will drive the need for a range of connectivity options.

For certain applications, latency will also be a concern. Lag time, for example, could create a disorienting effect for users of wearable devices such as Google Glass. In those situations where latency is a factor, organisations will need to put their data and computing infrastructure in close proximity to users and the devices, and be able to connect directly to their trading partners and digital supply chain.

Supply squeeze

IoT initiatives will leverage a combination of public cloud, private cloud and enterprise data centres. Regardless of the mix, it is conceivable that the trend will contribute to a squeeze on the supply of data centre and cloud resources, particularly in areas near large population centres, major metro areas or even industrial and manufacturing hubs, where data centre space is already at a premium.

While it is still too early to tell exactly how the IoT story will unfold over the next few years, one thing is clear: data centres will play a critical role. Any IoT initiative will require a tailored data centre strategy that balances current needs with future growth and potential applications involving governments, private enterprise and even consumers. Chief information officers will, therefore, need to think carefully about their data centre strategy to ensure it provides the flexibility, scalability, security, availability and connectivity that the emerging IoT trend will demand.

The writer is chief technology officer of Digital Realty

site_title: Airlines redraw flight paths to steer clear of Ukraine
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Airlines redraw flight paths to steer clear of Ukraine

MH17 tragedy may hit tourist arrivals in South-east Asia from Europe, say analysts

Nisha Ramchandani

Published

Fri, Jul 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

AS news of the downed Malaysia Airlines Flight MH17 reverberated around the world, airlines moved swiftly to re-route flight paths and avoid Ukrainian airspace.

Carriers, including Singapore Airlines, Thai Airways, Lufthansa and Air France, have re-routed flights, which could tack on additional flight time and fuel costs, resulting in flight delays. Thai Airways reportedly expects flight delays of up to half an hour for flights to and from Europe.

"At this point, we are no longer using Ukrainian airspace and have re-routed all our flights to alternative flight paths that are away from the region," said an SIA spokesman. The airline immediately made the changes after the MH17 incident on Thursday.

Other Asia-Pacific carriers - such as Korean Air, Asiana, Qantas Airways, Cathay Pacific and China Airlines - had started avoiding the airspace over eastern Ukraine months ago when Russia marched into Crimea, raising questions as to why other carriers hadn't followed suit.

But airline bodies International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO), International Air Transport Association (Iata) as well as European air traffic regulator Eurocontrol have stepped forward to point out that the flight path adopted by MH17 was not subject to restrictions.

Reacting to news of the Boeing 777 aircraft going down, Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak stressed that MH17's flight route was declared safe by United Nations' aviation body ICAO.

Kuala Lumpur-bound MH17 was flying at 33,000 feet when it fell off the radar, a level which was open at the time as Ukrainian authorities had only closed the route from ground to 32,000 feet, said Eurocontrol.

Since the crash, the Ukrainian authorities have closed off routes from the ground up to unlimited altitude, effectively declaring it a no-fly zone.

While National University of Singapore (NUS) professor Ted Hopf reckons that altering flight paths by a few hundred kilometres to bypass Ukrainian airspace shouldn't add significantly to the fuel bill for carriers, he also noted that the price of fuel could go up given simultaneous crises in Iraq, Gaza and Syria.

Brent crude futures rose to nearly US$108 per barrel in the wake of the MH17 crash. UOB Kay Hian analysts said SIA and Cathay Pacific have hedged most of their fuel requirements for the year, however, which could help insulate them from a spike in fuel prices. Prof Hopf also said it would be difficult for carriers to avoid flying over all hotspots as it means "having to avoid large swathes of the globe". Still, Korean Air Lines Co announced plans to suspend all flights to Tel Aviv over the next week to address flight safety concerns as Israel mounted a ground offensive in the Gaza Strip.

UOB Kay Hian analysts reckon that visitor arrivals from Europe to South-east Asia - which already have taken a hit in the wake of flight MH370's disappearance in March - could fall as a result of this latest tragedy, translating to lower passenger loads for South-east Asian carriers.

"A greater portion of the sector's air travel will now transit via the Middle Eastern or Turkish hubs," they wrote in a report.

Alicia Seah, director of marketing and communications for Dynasty Travel, told BT that Europe-bound travellers are concerned that airfares could rise if higher fuel costs are passed onto consumers, especially during the current peak travel season. While there is no indication of this at present, Ms Seah noted fares could rise in future if fuel surcharges trend higher.

Meanwhile, Singapore's Ministry of Foreign Affairs said yesterday that there have been no reports of Singaporeans on MH17 at this point.

MAS has released a list of the 298 passengers and crew by nationality, which included 189 Dutch passengers, 44 Malaysians and 27 Australians at last update. Four of the 298 have yet to be verified by MAS as they were transit passengers who boarded the plane in Amsterdam.

Seven passengers onboard MH17 were bound for Singapore, via Kuala Lumpur, BT understands.

"MFA remains in close contact with MAS and the relevant airport authorities to ascertain the nationality of the unverified passengers," the MFA said.

content:
SUBSCRIBERS

STI clings to 52-week high as geopolitical worries hit markets

Published

Fri, Jul 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

IT was a tragic end to a largely uneventful week as news of the downing of a Malaysia Airlines aircraft on Thursday over Ukraine led to a large selloff on Wall Street, raising geopolitical worries and dampening already fragile sentiment in markets everywhere.

However, the absence of liquidity and meaningful interest in Singapore may have helped stocks here escape relatively unscathed. After dropping slightly into the red, the Straits Times Index yesterday managed a net rise of 3.64 points to a new 52-week high of 3,310.53. This brings its gain for the week to 17 points or 0.5 per cent.

Turnover has been poor for many months now and yesterday's 1.5 billion units worth S$819 million was the seventh consecutive day that dollar business was under S$1 billion. Excluding warrants there were 191 rises against 207 falls.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average on Thursday dropped 161 points or 0.9 per cent to 16,976 and the S&P 500 lost 1.2 per cent to 1,958 after news of the crash reminded markets that Ukrainian political instability is very much a worry that until now has been brushed aside as inconsequential.

US news reports also mentioned Israel's offensive in Gaza and Hamas's retaliatory rocket strikes on Israel as factors behind the selling.

Here, United Overseas Bank has been the main blue chip in play throughout the week, with DBS and the Jardine group in supporting roles. UOB was queried by the Singapore Exchange (SGX) a week ago and after it replied that it did not know why its shares were in play, SGX issued a Trade With Caution notice. The stock yesterday bounced 10 cents to S$23.65; over the five days it lost 38 cents or 1.6 per cent.

In the second line, Jaya Holdings was queried by SGX on the unusual trading volume in its shares and, like UOB last week, received a Trade With Caution notice after it replied that it could not explain the unusual activity.

Jaya's shares fell 0.4 Singapore cents to 7.3 cents yesterday with 142 million traded. Formerly a shipping firm, Jaya is now a shell company after selling its business to Mermaid Marine Australia in June.

On the domestic front, the main news yesterday was that non-oil domestic exports (NODX) contracted 4.6 per cent year-on-year last month, after falling 6.6 per cent in May.

In its Daily Breakfast Spread yesterday, DBS Group Research asked why exports have been so disappointing and said the reason is that most people probably had been too optimistic about the global recovery, particular in the US.

"And when growth momentum slumped in the first quarter, the blame was on the bad weather," said DBS. "As it appears now, the recovery was never strong and probably will remain slow in the coming quarters. With such an outlook on the US, one can't reasonably expect a strong performance in Singapore's exports. This is further compounded by the fact that the Eurozone is unlikely to offer much respite and that China has decided to grow slower this year."

In its Rates Strategy yesterday, Rabobank said the airplane disaster and the situation in Gaza raise the clear risk of a spike in geopolitical tensions and a move to the highest quality assets.

"As noted in one of our comments earlier in the week, this bid for safe-haven assets could replace the anaesthetic of central bank stimulus if the latter were to recede. . .'' said the bank.

Cloud security a big concern for firms

There is a sense that applications and data stored in the public cloud are not as secure as when they are stored in a company's own servers, reports AMIT ROY CHOUDHURY

Published Sun, Jul 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

RECENT data from a number of research agencies show that cloud computing has become an integral part of the IT roadmap across almost all industry verticals. A recent study by Forrester Research found that the public cloud market is expected to reach US$191 billion by 2020, up from US$58 billion in 2013. Cloud applications will likely lead this growth and is forecast to hit US$133 billion in 2020. Cloud platforms will generate US$44 billion and cloud business services will reach US$14 billion.

Despite the high mindshare, security remains a major concern for chief information officers (CIOs). There is a sense that applications and data stored in the cloud, particularly the public cloud, are not as secure as when they are stored in the company's own servers.

BizIT asked Bill Padfield, chief executive officer of Dimension Data Asia Pacific, about what he sees in the market. Dimension Data is a major IT services company in the Asia-Pacific region; it helps companies implement their cloud strategy.

Commercial cards have huge growth potential, especially in SME sector

Banks here see good growth in customers and sales volume

Mindy Tan

Published Sun, Jul 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

[SINGAPORE] Even as banks in Singapore have seen double digit growth in the take-up of their commercial cards, there is still significant space for growth, particularly from small businesses.

Commercial cards - which encompasses both credit cards and debit cards - are issued for business use and often offer a range of rewards, including business-oriented discounts, cash rebates and travel benefits.

According to a survey conducted by Visa in 2011, 43 per cent of the 301 SME respondents said they use commercial cards. However, actual usage was low. In the category of travel and expenditure spend for instance, only 21 per cent of spend was captured on the commercial cards while 54 per cent was conducted via staff expense claims.

SUBSCRIBERS

Lobster on a roll

They're swaddled with mayonnaise, fried in butter but oh so delicious. Debbie Yong looks at why New England-style lobster rolls are suddenly trending here

Published Fri, Jul 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

MOVE aside, wagyu burgers. Lobster rolls are the gourmet fast food du jour. Essentially a butter-griddled hot dog bun stuffed with cold mayonnaise-coated lobster meat chunks, the luxe snack drew three hour-long queues when lobster-only Duxton eatery Pince and Pints opened its doors a fortnight ago. At least eight other restaurants now sell the rolls here, up from two some years ago.

But they weren't always so popular, recalls Nicholas Lin of seven-month-old Platypus Lobster Shack. When he first debuted his lobster rolls as a supplementary dinner-only option at his box-lunch outlet, Platypus Gourmet2Go, it was not particularly popular. "Only a handful of our customers actually knew what a lobster roll was," says Mr Lin, who now sells up to 400 lobster rolls weekly.

But why is the American seafood shack favourite - said to be born of 19th-century New England hostesses who thought the consumption of an entire lobster too messy for their elegant dinner parties - suddenly catching on here?

site_title: Accused changes tune, says he played role in church affairs
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Accused changes tune, says he played role in church affairs

Lam also challenged on his claim that companies like Xtron Productions were independent from CHC

Published Fri, Jul 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

ACCUSED City Harvest Church (CHC) member John Lam yesterday admitted on the stand to having been involved in every major decision of the church - a testimony in direct contrast to his lawyer's assertion earlier this week that Lam just "pops out here and there".

He was also challenged on his claim that companies such as Xtron Productions (which managed Sun Ho's singing career and the church's evangelical effort, the Crossover Project) were independent from CHC; the prosecution produced several documents pointing to CHC having called the shots for these companies.

Lam is among six CHC members charged with having "dishonestly misappropriated" some S$24 million of the church's building funds to finance Ms Ho's career, and with round-tripping another S$26.6 million, using entities such as Xtron, to cover the alleged misappropriation. The others on trial are Ms Ho's husband, senior pastor and co-founder Kong Hee, deputy senior pastor Tan Ye Peng, finance manager Sharon Tan, and former finance manager and board member Serina Wee.

Lam's lawyer, Senior Counsel Kenneth Tan, had said in his opening statement on Monday that Lam had played a much smaller role than the others in the transactions in question: "All John Lam is, is a volunteer . . . he seems to pop out here and there."

But, under cross-examination by the prosecution yesterday, Lam admitted to being involved in all major decisions of the church.

Chief prosecutor Mavis Chionh produced a transcript of an extraordinary general meeting held by CHC on July 7, 2007; at that meeting, Kong had described Lam, head of the church's investment committee, as being "very qualified" and who has "been with us in every major decision we've made from Day 1".

Ms Chionh asked Lam if it was correct to say he had been with the church in every major decision made from Day 1.

"Yes, I can agree with that," Lam replied.

She showed minutes of other meetings - one in March 2010 with the church's executive members, at which he addressed accusations made against Kong; at another meeting months later, he presented audit findings to the executive members.

"When we look at (these), the history of your involvement in the church, the key appointments you have held, the responsibilities you have held, it is clear that you are not just an ordinary member who happens to 'pop in and out' of the church," Ms Chionh said.

Lam disagreed, saying: "My statement, and as my counsel has said, regarding this case, my position has always been (that I) popped in and out . . . I'm not disagreeing that I'm qualified, that I have experience, but I am an ordinary volunteer."

He also asserted that entities such as Xtron, while aligned with CHC's objectives, were independent.

But Ms Chionh put it to him: "(On Thursday), you were the one who told us that (CHC senior pastor Kong Hee) wanted the directors of all these companies listed to be responsible for the running of their company . . . If these companies are all independent of the church, why should Mr Kong, as pastor of the church, be in a position to say that he wants the directors to be made responsible for the running of the companies?"

She produced evidence showing the church's role in the running of these companies - in particular, Xtron. The court was shown a document listing individuals whom Lam, Wee, Chew and Tan Ye Peng suggested to Kong and the CHC board as being suitable directors for the "independent" companies.

She also produced another document on the agreement between Xtron and CHC on CHC's subleasing of Singapore Expo Hall 8 from Xtron, for which Xtron did not charge the church a mark-up for renting the Expo space.

"Assuming Xtron is an independent commercial entity that deals with the church at arm's length, why is it that it would not charge any mark-up on the rental of Expo?" she asked.

Lam said he believed there was a mark-up provided for in the sub-leasing agreement. Ms Chionh then produced another document: an e-mail from Wee to senior church members which said a CHC board meeting had decided CHC would pay Xtron a mark-up, "as only then will it be deemed an arm's length transaction"; the e-mail also carried Wee's calculations on how the mark-up was to be done.

"Do you have any explanation as to why, if Xtron is an independent commercial entity, . . . is Serina (Wee), the church's finance manager, proposing in this e-mail how much mark-up Xtron should charge CHC for renting the Expo premises? It doesn't make sense for the church, if it is dealing at arm's length with Xtron, a commercial entity, to say, 'Hey, I want to pay you more rent than you are now charging me. Please, can I pay you more rent?' You would expect Xtron to be the one to propose a rental mark-up. Do you agree?"

Lam, not answering the question directly, only said that CHC was prepared to pay a mark-up because it wanted Xtron to be independent.

"Mr Lam, if you have no answer to what I've been asking for the last 10 minutes, I suggest to you then that what we see here (in the e-mail) suggests that your evidence about City Harvest and Xtron being two entities that operate independently of each other and at arm's length is not true. Do you agree or disagree?"

"I disagree," Lam said.

The hearing is adjourned until Aug 4.

site_title: Tiered data plans, fibre broadband revenue closely watched
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Tiered data plans, fibre broadband revenue closely watched

Published

Fri, Jul 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

THE great migration to tiered data plans will be closely watched this year, as the quarterly earnings season for the Big Three operators is set to begin.

Already, by the end of the first quarter of 2014, the proportion of tiered data plan users out of the postpaid user base had hit new highs of 50 per cent or more across the operators.

This proportion is expected to reach 70 per cent by year-end, Maybank Kim Eng Research's Gregory Yap reckoned in his May report on the telco sector.

"Data monetisation accelerated in Q1 2014, driving mobile revenue to record levels with growth rate at its fastest in more than four quarters," Mr Yap had noted.

For the rest of the year, the rate of conversion to tiered data plans will be even more crucial, given how StarHub became the first telco here to start charging new and recontracting customers an additional S$2.14 for 4G speeds this month.

Analysts believe that this charge might discourage mobile subscribers who are out of contract with SingTel or M1 from switching to StarHub.

Already, some postpaid subscribers hanging on to their older plans with large monthly data caps of 12 gigabytes (GB) have little incentive to migrate to a tiered plan with smaller data allowances, OCBC Investment Research's Carey Wong pointed out.

A catalyst for more migration to tiered data plans might come this September, when the iPhone 6 is expected to be released.

Even then, those on the older plans might choose to stay put and pay for the handset, without the benefit of an operator handset subsidy.

"But that also works in the telco's favour," OCBC's Mr Wong said, as the operator saves on subscriber acquisition costs in the form of handset subsidies.

Already, subscriber acquisition costs are on their way down, partially because of the mix of handsets sold. For the full year ended March 31, 2014, SingTel saw a 15.9 per cent easing in acquisition cost per postpaid customer here, from S$302 to S$254.

"Fast-falling handset subsidies are another positive trend that would benefit margins," Maybank Kim Eng Research's Mr Yap noted in his May report.

On the fibre broadband front, things are expected to heat up in an already competitive environment. In previous quarters, the telcos have taken hits from new and smaller fibre broadband players entering the market with cutthroat prices.

This is set to continue, with fibre broadband average revenue per user expected to dip further or stay flat, analysts say.

And while the spectre of a fourth telco looms now that broadband firm MyRepublic wants in on the full-fledged telco scene, industry watchers do not seem particularly perturbed.

A UOB Kay Hian report earlier this week noted how some fund managers have "questioned the business case" for incurring the massive capital expenditure that a fourth player would need, given the current high penetration rate.

The report maintained its "overweight" rating on the telco sector. "In the near term, we remain positive on M1 due to positive trends for mobile, such as increased usage of data and lower handset subsidies," the report said.

"We see SingTel as a hedge against regulatory risk in Singapore, and there could be a potential reversal of yield compression."

site_title: Co-work operations
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Co-work operations

Much has changed since Hackerspace, Singapore's first co-working space, opened in Singapore in 2009. Debbie Yong and Georgine Verano give updates on new collaborative working communities - with a difference

Published

Fri, Jul 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Woolf Works

176 Joo Chiat Rd, #02-01 Tel 9002 3724

info@woolfworks.sg

www.facebook.com/WoolfWorksSg

AH, the power of great writers to articulate sentiments that hold true long after they're gone. When Virginia Woolf wrote her 1923 essay A Room Of One's Own, did she know that it would later become the inspiration for Singapore's first women-only co-working space?

Christened Woolf Works in tribute, the week-old space in Joo Chiat is Michaela Anchan's circa-2014 manifestation of Woolf's belief that "a woman must have money and a room of her own if she is to write fiction". The New Zealand native felt that message keenly. She juggles dual roles as a writer of short stories and fiction and as a stay-home mother with two children aged five and 12. She says: "After taking care of the kids and the family, I hardly get any free time or space at home where I can focus on my writing."

That kicked off her search for a personal office space six months ago, which was shortly called off when the options proved too costly. Then she discovered the concept of co-working. "I thought maybe other women and mothers in the same predicament could benefit from a collective space," says Ms Anchan.

Besides, as an active member of several business networking groups for women, "I enjoy the energy of women working together and very often we have to deal with the same struggles such as balancing our domestic responsibilities with our personal ambitions," she says. Open to "anyone from business professionals to writers and bloggers", Woolf Works additionally targets a group that Ms Anchan believes to be growing: the "mum-preneur", or stay-home mothers turned entrepreneurs.

Existing co-working spaces in the Central Business District tend to be too corporate for this group, while the more edgy co-working spaces are typically skewed towards technology entrepreneurs, she says.

What Ms Anchan wanted to create instead was "a calm and peaceful space for women looking for a place where they can be themselves", she says. Besides the usual office amentities such as free wireless Internet access, printing facilities, a library of magazines and business publications, and a cosy meeting room that seats up to three, the 1,400 sq ft space on the second floor of a Joo Chiat shophouse has plenty of female-oriented features.

A bouquet of fresh flowers is delivered by neighbourhood florist, Hiew, daily. Soft music plays in the background and the communal pantry is stocked with Sarnies coffee and healthy snacks such as dried fruit and nuts from local brand, Fave. Lots of wide open spaces and a white and bright yellow colour palette conceptualised by a Dutch architect-friend gives the space an airy, contemporary feel.

"I've even had someone enquire if she could sign up just to have a quiet space where she can read a book," laughs Ms Anchan.

Rates start at S$500 for the five permanent desks and part-time use for the 25 "hot desks" are charged at S$200, S$300 and S$400 monthly for weekly, twice weekly and thrice weekly visits. Or drop in on an ad-hoc basis for S$50 per day. Permanent members get 24/7 use of the space, whereas others can use the space from 9am to 6pm daily. A conference room upstairs that can hold 12 people seated and 25 standing can be booked for S$40 per hour and upwards - for everything from business meetings to group pilates classes.

Ms Anchan will engage guest speakers to conduct professional workshops on goal-setting and business incorporation in the space, along with regular business networking social events for women. Talks start from next week and are free for members (S$5 per entry for the public).

A tad too sexist? While men can't sign up as members, they can, however, accompany members as guests for these events, says Ms Anchan. On the rise in popularity of co-working spaces, she observes: "The nature of how we all work is changing. More people are choosing to work from home these days and office space is simultaneously getting more and more expensive."

If this space takes off, she would like to open further spaces in the western part of Singapore, preferably next to a childcare centre. "But let's do this one step at a time," she says.

DRAWN TO CO-WORKING

Art Social Haus

#10-08 Oxley Bizhub 2

62 Ubi Road 1

www.facebook.com/artsocialhaus

AS anyone who has dabbled in creating art can attest, it is a messy affair.

Paint splatters and stains. Solvents stink up the room. The cat might trample all over your drying masterpiece, and good luck trying to pack all of that up quickly when your children demand that your "art studio" - really the family dining table - be returned at meal times.

So weary of having to deal with such issues were graphic designers Sheau Chan and Erica Tsirtsakis that the two women came together to start art-centric co-working studio, Art Social Haus, last month.

"We initially thought of renting an art studio to share between us, but since we both have full-time jobs, we decided to find a place we could open up to others like us to fully utilise the space," says Ms Chan. Both she and Australia-raised Argentinian Ms Tsirtsakis work with foreign design agencies based here. They met two years ago when Ms Tsirtsakis attended a diploma course in visual design that Ms Chan taught.

Positioned somewhere between a professional art studio and an art-jamming space, where amateur artists rent easels, brushes and paints on an hourly basis, Art Social Haus is targeted at "people who are slightly more serious than the hobbyist painter, but who are not established enough yet to be able to afford a studio of their own" - such as fresh graduates from the various art schools, says Ms Chan. Her day-job is also based out of a co-working space in the Central Business District.

"Most artists like to work on their own, but sometimes when you run out of inspiration, it's also nice to have people to talk to or just to walk around the premises to see what others are doing," she adds.

Rates at Art Social Haus start from S$280 per person per month, which gets you a 1.5 m by 1.2 m personal workspace that includes an easel, a stool and a trolley. Members also have free use of communal facilities such as two manual inking stations for print makers, a large wooden table for meetings, a cosy sofa lounge with a pantry stocked with teas and coffee, and a bathroom with an industrial metal sink. Dry on inspiration? Dip in the outdoor pool or take a treadmill break in the shared gym on the top floor in the brand new light industrial building. Art Social Haus can fit up to 10 easels and eight work desks for a total of 15 people at full capacity. There is minimum rental period of six months for desks and three months for easels. For the non-committal artist, workstations are also open for daily rentals on weekends at S$35 per 4-hour morning or afternoon session, and S$60 for a full eight-hour stretch.

Each monthly member will be given an access key which gives them 24-hour access to the studio, "because we know a lot of creative people are most productive from midnight to sunrise," laughs Ms Chan. "We want to create a community where people can feel comfortable, learn from each other, even bake cookies to share with one another," adds Ms Tsirtsakis of the 1,000 sq ft rectangular room kitted out with hand-restored kitchenware and second-hand furniture from the Salvation Army. In the spirit of camaraderie, members who sign up for monthly rentals can opt to share the space with up to two other friends for S$350 per person for two people per month; and S$400 per person per month for a three-person sharing arrangement.

All members get to hold one free exhibition held at the space within the membership period. There are no restrictions on the types of artists and their mediums that the space can accommodate, say Ms Chan and Ms Tsirtsakis, who hope to attract everyone from painters to sculptors, and printmakers to ceramic artists to sign up.

The two women plan to gradually host creative workshops showcasing less conventional art forms such as tattoo art, talks by female artists, poetry readings and even art-themed whisky and food pairing dinners in the space. Groups of painters can also rent the easel spaces collectively for private tutelage and events.

The place will not be manned by a community manager all the time, adds Ms Tsirtsakis. "We hope to encourage people to take ownership of the space. We're not a stiff service office."

TEAM-BUILDING, LITERALLY

The Tool Room

12 Dunlop Street Tel 8233 9810

http://toolroom.me

WHEN the going gets tough, the really tough keep going at it - with a hammer.

That's what cocktail bar owner Abhishek Cherian George did when he found out that the Little India shophouse he had taken over could not get a liquor licence. No, he wasn't unleashing a vengeful rampage for his dashed dreams of running a second speakeasy in the area. The hammering and sawing was part of Mr George's Plan B: to transform the three-storey shophouse into the co-working space of his dreams. "The objective was to solve all the problems I had when I was trying to find a place to work," says Mr George of The Tool Room, which opened last month.

For the sufferer of chronic back problems, this meant equipping each workstation with eye-level monitors, standing-height desks, personal orthotic Equilibras slippers and, depending on the membership package you take up, even S$800 ergonomically designed Locus Seats. Worked too late into the night and missed the last train home? Just hop on one of the four foldable bicycles that you can borrow to get home. Or take a quick nap till morning on the "napping loft" upstairs.

The three-level shophouse has 12 workstations on the ground floor, with 10 more under construction on the second floor. Membership comes in three tiers, priced from S$650 to S$850, and drawing on Mr George's F&B background - he also runs Boat Quay speakeasy The Spiffy Dapper and Dapper Coffee - some of the packages entitle members to personal bar fridges stocked with 20 bottles of cold-brew coffee every month, and complimentary cocktails when they visit the bar. The space cost $120,000 and four months to set up - half of what it would have cost if he had hired contractors instead of doing everything up himself.

Tembusu Terminal, the makers of Singapore's first Bitcoin ATM, are permanent tenants. The space will be an incubator of sorts for the private equity business that Mr George hopes to launch in the future, along with a second F&B outlet by year-end.

INCUBATOR WITH SOME JAVA JIVE

The Cub

48 Niven Road

THERE may be no such thing as a free lunch, but a free office space? Perhaps, though it comes with one catch: it is only for the very enterprising.

To get a seat at The Cub - a large oval meeting table that fits up to 12 around it - you have to first pitch your business idea to venture capitalist Joel Sng. For the table sits in the middle of the hubbub in a 2,000 sq ft shophouse along Niven Road, an office and startup incubator for the various businesses that Mr Sng invests in.

He explains the generosity: "We want to give out the space to support budding entrepeneurs, I have excess capacity. Even if I charge S$100 a month for a seat, it doesn't move the needle from a returns point of view."

Even if the pitch is not successful, startups are welcome to use the space. "I don't see it as a loss, if they are here for awhile and we've shared great ideas and learnt from each other, there's value in that too," says Mr Sng, a Harvard graduate who runs his family's investment business, and who co-founded a venture capital firm, Formation 8, which also runs out of the shophouse. Two of his other businesses, LifeOpp, a site which pairs jobseekers with employers started last March, and Asiagenomics, which owns the distribution rights for genomics testing in Singapore, occupy the rest of the space.

Startups at The Cub can get legal advice from Mr Sng's legal team and "piggy back on good rates" offered by partner accounting firms, he says. Besides free Internet connection, budding entrepeneurs can also lounge in a nook at the back of the second floor furnished with colourful bean bags and carpet grass, or hold more formal discussions in a glass-encased meeting room that seats up to eight.

Startups which have used the space range from single-person ventures to a four-man team, and include businesses such as Learnemy, an online marketplace for teachers and students, and Mr Huntly, an online global network of headhunters. There is no time limit to how long startups can use the space, says Mr Sng, but there is one rule: Everyone has to come in at 9am. "It promotes discipline and keeps you on track," he explains. Tenants are welcome to stay on to work through the night, if they prefer.

Should a caffeine kick be required, there's Whale & Cloud, a colourful office pantry stocked with coffee beans that Mr Sng has accumulated from his business trips around the world, and used by the various startups for meetings with their clients and potential investors on weekdays.

When the office is shut on weekends, the 300 sq ft space morphs into a weekend-only cafe-cum-retail store that has been gradually drawing a steady stream of largely young expatriate residents from the condominiums nearby and local cafe-hoppers. You enter the cafe through the back alley by knocking on a closed door numbered 48 and 3/4.

CO-LIVING FOR LIKE-MINDED

13

13 Lorong 24A Geylang

http://thirteen.99.co

WORK-LIFE separation? So last generation.

According to Darius Cheung, there is a growing demand for people who want to sleep where they work. Six months ago, he founded 13, a co-working and co-living space "for people who want to live with a purpose," he says.

Named for its house number and part of the Lorong 24A Shophouse Series collective of architect-designed conservation shophouses in Geylang, 13 is a sprawling 4,000 sq ft, five-storey shophouse that comprises six reidential rooms and 15 co-working office desks that can be rented on a monthly basis.

While the co-living concept isn't new - similar projects exist in cities such as New York, Berlin, Stockholm, Kyoto and even Matera in rural Italy, where residents have individual rooms but share community-managed work spaces and facilities - 13 was particularly inspired by Mr Cheung's two weeks spent in the eight-room Sandbox House in Berkeley and the 30-room Embassy in San Francisco last year. There, he observed technology entrepreneurs living among designers and food innovators who manned the apartments' edible gardens, recalls Mr Cheung, who is also the co-founder of 99.co, an online apartment rental search platform.

The all en-suite rooms at 13 range from 300 sq ft to 800 sq ft in size and cost between S$1,300 and S$2,000 in monthly rent. Each resident has to commit to a minimum stay of six months, as required by law, and potential housemates are first invited to the house's dinners or monthly house parties that gather the local startup community to see if they would fit in with the mix.

There is no strict criteria as to who can join as residents, but Mr Cheung believes the unconventional nature of the space and its Geylang location makes it a "self-selecting process". "We did have some bankers who were keen to live here because of the space, but they didn't quite fit in with the rest of the housemates so we had to say no," says Mr Cheung.

The house is currently fully tenanted out to a French couple who work in fashion, a graphic designer from England, a fashion designer from India, a Singapore-educated Indian national who runs a startup specialising in drone technology, and the teams behind software engineering company Watt Digital and short film online platform Viddsee.

Besides the rooms, there are also 15 "hot desks" that non-residents can rent for S$350 a month, which includes 24-hour access to the shophouse and all its facilities and events. The open-counter kitchen is fitted with a projector screen so it can double as a meeting room in the day time.

While 13 is "just barely breaking even" for now, "we're not doing it for profit, but because it's interesting," says Mr Cheung, who came across the shophouse when visiting an art exhibition in a neighbouring unit last year.

"It could be profitable if we took a less costly space, but we intentionally wanted a place that is design-centric and inspiring," he adds. Other units in the Shophouse Series have a current tag of S$9,000 to S$11,000 in monthly rent.

While Mr Cheung believes there is room for more co-living projects in Singapore, particularly another one close to the local universities and the startup hub at Block 71, Ayer Rajah, in the western parts of Singapore, he has no concrete plans to launch a second venue yet.

"It was very risky at first, we didn't know if anyone would even be interested," he admits.

By Debbie Yong

debyong@sph.com.sg

@DebbieYongBT

ONE-STOP SHOPS FOR STARTUPS

Home-Fix XPC (Experience Centre)

19 Tai Seng Avenue, Home-Fix Building #06-01 Tel 6671 9000

www.home-fix.com

Mon - Fri: 9.30am-6.30pm; Sat: 10am-6.30pm; Closed on Sundays and public holidays

STARTED by hardware store Home-Fix's founder and managing director Low Cheong Kee, Home-Fix XPC is the third in a series of "makerspaces" to have opened here this year, and possibly the largest.

A makerspace is an area that provides not only co-working space but also tools and workshop facilities for members. The 10,000 sq ft Home-Fix XPC is really a large workshop and office that sits on the first two levels of Home-Fix's headquarters in Tai Seng Avenue.

What was originally intended to be a knowledge resource centre for hardware enthusiasts to meet and swap ideas developed into a "makerspace" late last year when Mr Low was approached by the Singapore Makers - an online community of about 1,000 enthusiasts (600 of whom are in contact with Home-Fix) - who were looking to use Home-Fix's headquarters to host Maker Meetups. XPC is fully equipped to house those whose projects range from woodworking to electronics and 3D printing. Level 2 is divided into four glass-walled rooms housing a meeting room, a prototyping lab, an electronics room with benches lined with power tools and a well-stocked workshop which provides materials such as table saws and drills.

For added convenience, they've even set up a materials store, where members can purchase wood, fabric or other materials for their projects. Ernest Hu, the creative executive who runs XPC's operations, says that they are planning to move the workshop areas to the first floor, and provide more co-working spaces for members.

Though it was only started in June, Home-Fix XPC's roster of members now includes a full-time carpenter, 3D printer developers and even a bicycle crafter. Mr Hu says that although not all the spaces have been taken up yet, reaction has been strong enough for them to further expand the co-working space. Members can utilise the space from S$20 daily to SS$400 monthly. For S$20, you get to use the workshop space and all its tools, equipment and machines for a day. You will be assigned a workbench with your personal tools. For a monthly rate of S$120, you will receive unlimited access to the same facilities for a month, and for SS$400 a month, you will receive a co-working table, free Wi-Fi as well as free use of the pantry, workshop and meeting rooms. For uncompleted projects, there is an optional storage locker for S$50 per month.

The Merry Men Collective

315 Outram Road, Tan Boon Liat Building #05-01 Tel 6223 6856

www.tmmcollective.com

THE Merry Men Collective, owned by Shawn Heng and Eugene Fung, is a co-working space for companies to work not just side by side, but together.

The partners purchased the space in the Tan Boon Liat building two months ago while hunting for an office of their own. Although it was too big for their still-growing company, they didn't want to pass up on the sun-soaked space with its 3m-high ceilings. This, in turn, inspired sharing the space with like-minded startups, creatives, or young businesses which did not need or could not afford a proper office space.

Mr Heng and his partner engaged an interior designer friend to help them redesign the 1,600 sq ft space, with 14 tables, a meeting room at the back as well as a pantry for their clients. Being in the bar business, they incorporated a mini-bar section that fully stocks beers, champagnes and wines for clients as well.

Rentals range from S$500 to S$600 a month; S$500 gets you a standard desk with four storage shelves, while S$600 gets you a slightly larger desk with eight storage shelves. Mr Heng insists they're not in this for the money - they even have a barter system with some clients, swapping skills for rental payment. One example is photographer Joshua Sim, who owns The Beautiful Moment Photography, whom Mr Heng says takes photos for The Merry Men Collective in exchange for rental sometimes. Clients are also carefully chosen.

His ideal crowd? A mix of Web and graphic designers, photographers and brand or marketing startups, that will be able to create a more open vibe, offering one another assistance and networking.

site_title: Serving up multiple brands
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Serving up multiple brands

Japan Foods is also taking the manpower shortage and rising rentals in its stride, reports ANDREA SOH

Published

Sun, Jul 20, 2014 · 10:00 PM

LOCAL food and beverage firms have been struggling with the twin pressures of manpower shortage and rising rental costs. Japan Foods, the group behind Japan- themed restaurants such as Ajisen Ramen, Menya Musashi and Osaka Ohsho, is however taking these in its strides - having put in the necessary measures in the past years.

Just this year, in view of a staff shortage and the need to raise salaries to keep its existing staff, the group started placing an iPad at every table in its restaurants, enabling patrons to place their orders themselves. This helps the group keep expenses in check. "We will increase salaries, but we're going to reduce the number of staff," says chief executive officer Takahashi Kenichi in an interview with The Business Times.

There will, of course, be some customers who don't know how to use the iPads. When that happens, there are staff on stand-by to help them, he says. "But 90 per cent (of our customers) can do it."

Besides the iPad menu, Japan Foods in 2007 expanded the small central kitchen it had since 2002. Now, the facility at Kampong Ampat makes everything from gyozas to salmon teriyaki.

"So our restaurant operations are kept simple, and this reduces the need for manpower," the engineer- turned-entrepreneur explains.

On top of that, the group bought its own noodle machines three years ago. Cost-cutting measures such as these, as well as a strong Singapore dollar against the Japanese yen, have helped to reduce the proportion of Japan Food's materials cost from 21.7 per cent in the 2012 financial year to 18.4 per cent in the 2014 financial year.

Asked about escalating rental costs, which have been voiced by many a retailer, Mr Kenichi says that the increases have been acceptable for the group so far and within "single-digit levels".

An astute sense of what landlords want has helped. "Customers and management (of shopping malls) are always looking for new brands," he says. Hence, while Ajisen is the main brand for the group, Japan Foods has also branched into new brands, especially since 2008.

"Landlords want new ones, especially when they build a new shopping centre . . . And if I have many brands, in a good shopping centre, we can put three to four brands."

Of the group's 45 outlets in Singapore, three are in Ang Mo Kio hub and VivoCity each, while four are in Bugis Junction. This approach also lends the group greater negotiation power when the time comes for renewal of leases.

Another advantage of having multiple brands is that when one brand doesn't work, the group can easily substitute it with another. For example, when the group's dessert brand Let's Sweets at Bugis Junction and Junction 8 started performing badly about six months after its launch in 2010, Japan Foods switched the space to other brands.

"Conversion costs aren't too high," says Mr Kenichi.

The group's relationships with landlords are so important, it was partly why Japan Foods embarked on the listing route. The restaurant operator launched its initial public offering in February 2009, bravely staring down low valuations in the capital markets after the global financial crisis.

The group said then that it was optimistic about the defensive nature of the food and beverage industry, even under difficult economic conditions. But more important than raising funds from the IPO was increasing the group's appeal to customers and landlords, says Mr Kenichi.

"Many ramen shops were coming, and if a landlord has good space, it could give (that space) to either us or the newcomers. So with the IPO, we could get a better place, and also at a slightly better price."

The increased competition it saw then included famous Japanese ramen chain Ippudo, which opened here in October 2009. Now, ramen chains, including BreadTalk's Ramenplay and Marutama Ra-Men, are commonplace - a far cry from the time Ajisen first started in Singapore in 1997, when people here mistook ramen for laksa.

The IPO also helped to raise the profile of the group, with Japanese restaurants contacting Japan Foods for collaboration opportunities after that. In the past, it was a one-way courtship process with Mr Kenichi doing the pursuing.

With various franchise licences under its belt, Japan Foods is now looking for joint venture partners in Southeast Asia, especially since the group holds the licence for the Ajisen brand in Malaysia, Indonesia and Vietnam as well.

Already, the group has had a successful joint venture collaboration with Ajisen China (Holding) for the Menya Musashi brand in Hong Kong and China, a market where a strong local partner with good relationships with landlords is critical, Mr Kenichi says.

In Singapore, it plans to bring in one or two new brands in the next few years, possibly opening up to 100 outlets in a few years. The group had only 27 outlets when it listed.

"The Singapore market is quite small, but if you have a lot of brands, it's fine," he says. "It's competitive but from our results you can see that we've been progressing every year."

In the longer term, the group could possibly expand beyond just running restaurants. While now it makes food for its own outlets at the central kitchen, in future it could sell these to other restaurant firms and directly to consumers through supermarkets.

The group closed its financial year on March 31 setting a new record for both its revenue and net profit, and prompting its board to raise its annual target dividend ratio from 35 per cent to 40 per cent of its audited net profit. With a cash hoard of S$19 million and no borrowings, Japan Foods will hardly have any trouble meeting such increased dividend obligations.

site_title: ADB trims S-E Asia growth forecast for this year to 4.7%
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

ADB trims S-E Asia growth forecast for this year to 4.7%

Published

Fri, Jul 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Tokyo

SOUTH-EAST Asia appears relatively weak at present amid an otherwise stable outlook for economic growth across the Asia region as a whole, the Asian Development Bank said in a report yesterday.

Elsewhere, China is achieving a planned and controlled economic slowdown while India and Pakistan are picking up speed, the ADB said in its latest Asian Development Outlook (ADO) update.

Strengthening growth in Japan is helping offset softer economic expansion in the US but even so, the ADB has scaled back from 1.9 per cent to 1.5 per cent the forecast it made in April for growth this year in major industrialised countries. Growth in the 45 emerging economies of Asia is still forecast to reach 6.2 per cent in 2014 and 6.4 per cent next year, however, the ADB said.

"External demand is forecast to be somewhat weak as the moderate pace of growth in developing Asia persists and as strengthening in the major industrial economies, in particular the US, disappoints earlier expectations," the report warned.

"Growth in South-east Asia softened in the first half of 2014 largely because of country-specific factors in Indonesia, Thailand, and Vietnam," it noted.

In Indonesia, growth in the first quarter of 2014 slowed to 5.2 per cent as soft external demand, low commodity prices, and a temporary ban on exports of selected minerals undermined recovery in net exports, the ADB said. Domestic demand remained robust, however, with growth in private consumption driven by election spending, easing inflation and improved consumer confidence.

Thailand's political deadlock, meanwhile, has affected domestic demand and tourism there. The Thai economy contracted by 0.6 per cent in the first quarter and is likely to have contracted further in the second quarter. However, improved consumer confidence since the military takeover in May is a tentative sign that a modest recovery may take hold in the second half of the year.

Vietnam's growth forecast has been slightly reduced by the ADB to account for tensions with China and their effect on economic activity, including recent factory riots. Growth forecasts for other South-east Asian economies are generally in line with ADO 2014 expectations.

The 2014 forecast for the South-east Asia sub-region has been downgraded by 0.3 percentage points by the ADB to 4.7 per cent. But as the factors slowing growth in 2014 are expected to be temporary, the forecast growth of 5.4 per cent in 2015 has been maintained.

"Developing Asia as a region continues to perform well," ADB's deputy chief economist Juzhong Zhuang said in a statement accompanying the Manila-based development bank's latest bi-annual update of regional economic prospects.

"The pace of the growth moderation in China is in line with our expectations while the stage is set for India to pursue reform that could unlock its growth potential," the report said.

China's growth "is moderating in line with earlier expectations and should achieve the (ADB'S) forecast 7.5 per cent in 2014 and 7.4 per cent in 2015, while East Asia as a whole is similarly paced to meet growth projections of 6.7 per cent in both 2014 and 2015".

Industrial production in China expanded by 8.8 per cent in the second quarter, slightly above the 8.7 per cent growth recorded in the first quarter, the ADB said.

"More rapid expansion of services lifted their growth rate to 8 per cent for the first half of the year from 7.8 per cent in the first quarter. Retail sales grew by 10.8 per cent in the second quarter of 2014, pointing to healthy consumer demand. Real estate indicators, by contrast, signal continued weakness but this is compensated by accelerated infrastructure investment."

With parliamentary elections over, India is expected to pursue long-delayed reforms, the ADB suggested.

"India's growth forecast is maintained at 5.5 per cent in fiscal year 2014 but upgraded to 6.3 per cent in fiscal year 2015. With this improved outlook for the largest economy in South Asia, expansion in the sub-region is expected to reach 5.4 per cent in 2014 and pick up to 6.1 per cent in 2015."

Japan, meanwhile, grew by a "robust" seasonally adjusted annual rate of 6.7 per cent in the first quarter 2014, driven by both private consumption and investment, the ADB report noted.

Japan's stronger performance in the first quarter of 2014 suggests slightly faster growth in 2014, now forecast at 1.5 per cent, up from 1.3 per cent in April, the report said.

Declining food prices and relatively stable oil prices are meanwhile keeping developing Asia's inflation in check at 3.5 per cent in 2014 and 3.7 per cent in 2015, it added.

site_title: Shanghai bourse's int'l board shelved
content:
Shanghai bourse's int'l board shelved

Published

Fri, Jul 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

THE Shanghai Stock Exchange's (SSE) international board, which will allow foreign companies to list on the mainland, is on the back-burner as China's immediate focus has shifted to reforming the IPO and listing regime for domestic shares. These reforms, however, are expected to bring many benefits.

For a start, the Stock Connect between Hong Kong and Shanghai that opens the way for Chinese residents to buy Hong Kong shares and for Hong Kong investors to buy shares on the Shanghai bourse will be a booster to the languishing A-share market, and there is market talk that this initiative could be extended to London and Singapore in the future.

SSE chief economist Hu Ruyin told BT: "When the domestic listing regime is liberalised and the valuations are right, that will be a good window for the Shanghai international board to be launched, and by then, it can be rolled out fairly quickly."

For now, a conducive market for domestic companies to raise funds is more critical, said Dr Hu in Mandarin on the sidelines of the Future China Forum yesterday, after delegates were told that mom-and-pop investors account for some 99 per cent of total trading accounts in China and 80 per cent of trading volumes.

Several reforms are underway to stimulate the lacklustre A-shares and spur growth of the underdeveloped stock market. The Stock Connect between Shanghai and Hong Kong could be extended to Singapore and London in 2016, projected Cheah Cheng Hye, chairman of Asian-based fund Value Partners Group.

China also lifted a 14-month moratorium on initial public offerings in January; the unprecedented ban had closed a crucial exit door for many private equity firms on their investments and created a huge backlog of companies wanting to tap the market for funds.

Since the IPO market's reopening, 52 IPOs have raised 35 billion yuan (S$7 billion) in Shanghai and Shenzhen, said Frank Lyn, PwC China & Hong Kong markets leader. He added that the Chinese Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) has projected another 100 IPOs in the second half of the year (it is not usual for regulators elsewhere to make such market forecasts), reflecting the influence that Chinese regulators still have on the stock market.

The Shanghai and Shenzhen stock exchanges have a combined market capitalisation of 23 trillion yuan but they are not home to the largest and most profitable Chinese Internet giants Baidu, Alibaba and Tencent, which have streamed to the US bourse. "This reflects a major failure of the Chinese securities market in that it is not providing the services that it ought to be providing," Dr Hu said.

The new reforms seek to address these inadequacies by shifting the IPO regime from approval-based to registration-based, with IPO prices set by the market rather than the government. Delisting rules are also being introduced to get loss-making companies and those that have breached regulations to delist.

"The pricing mechanism is distorted," Dr Hu said. "Some large blue- chip companies have low valuations of not even one times of earnings while there is too much speculation in small caps. With the market opening up, there will be greater rationality and more investors undertaking value investing."

This market infancy has also hindered the introduction of listed Reits and business trusts, despite the many years that the regulator spent on preparing a listing framework for these products.

CapitaLand China deputy CEO Lucas Loh said at a panel discussion that if such a platform becomes available in China, this would provide another funding source for developers and local governments, and serve as an exit option for capital recycling. Retail investors would also have another option of investing in real estate, giving the sector greater sustainability.

Dr Hu told BT that with the outlook for Chinese developers clouded by fears of "bubbles" in some companies, rolling out such a listing framework now would be tough. "With more product innovation, investor sophistication also has to go up."

site_title: The best and worst of the 2014 World Cup
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

The best and worst of the 2014 World Cup

Germany signal their arrival as a new world power in football, while a few traditional giants of the game must do some serious soul searching

Published

Fri, Jul 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SIXTY-FOUR games in 32 days with a record-equalling 171 goals in all, the 2014 edition of the Fifa World Cup in Brazil is already being hailed as one of the best, if not the most outstanding, in the tournament's 84-year history.

The group stages provided most of the action, as the goals flew in at breakneck pace and many of the world's top footballing countries - among them Spain, Italy, England and Portugal - bid an early goodbye.

The knockout rounds also delivered their fair share of drama and upsets. There were perhaps more goalless draws than fans would have liked to see, but then again we were also treated to a rare display of football perfection when Germany tore up the history books by beating hosts Brazil 7-1 in the semi-finals.

As we look back on an amazing tournament, it's time to recognise those who played their part in making this year's World Cup the most memorable of all time.

Best team: Germany

This was the easiest category to declare a winner. The Germans were more than deserving of their first World Cup trophy in 24 long years. Teamwork, discipline, talent, charisma and sheer determination, this youthful squad had all of these traits in abundance. They swept past some of the biggest names in the sport with ease and all signs point to a long period of German dominance in The Beautiful Game.

Best coach: Louis van Gaal (The Netherlands)

Germany's Joachim Loew was a hot favourite for this honour, but the nod goes to the Dutch boss for transforming a team that put in a disgraceful showing at the 2010 final to a cohesive unit that played attractive, attacking football. Holland ended their World Cup campaign unbeaten and left with the bronze medal after trouncing Brazil 3-0 in the third-place playoff match.

Van Gaal's standing as one of the world's top managers has been boosted many times over, and he will hope to deliver the same level of success with his new employers, Manchester United, when the new English Premier League season kicks off next month.

Best player: James Rodriguez (Colombia)

How this youngster was not named Player of the Tournament is beyond me. Argentina's Lionel Messi eventually took home the Golden Ball award, but it doesn't take a genius to figure out who the real star of the World Cup was. The 23-year-old Rodriguez had a breakout performance in his country's five games in Brazil, scoring a tournament-high six goals in the process. He was voted Man of the Match against Uruguay, Ivory Coast and Greece.

Best goal: Mario Goetze (Germany)

Goetze's amazing extra-time goal in the final against Argentina stands out not just for its sheer quality, but also for the significance of being the one that won Germany their fourth World Cup trophy. Goetze, who had been on the field for barely half-an-hour after coming on as a second-half substitute, took Andre Schurrle's cross neatly on his chest before volleying the ball straight into the net. World class.

Biggest surprise: Costa Rica

I had declared the Latin Americans the most surprising nation of the World Cup after the group stages, and I haven't changed my mind since. Costa Rica, tipped to be one of the minnows, topped a group that contained Uruguay, England and Italy. They then went on to beat Greece in a penalty shoot-out to reach the quarter-finals for the first time, where they lost to the Netherlands on penalties after a heroic 0-0 draw.

Algeria was a close second for this honour, the North Africans making it to the Round of 16 for the first time where they gave Germany an almighty scare before losing 1-2 in extra time.

Biggest flops: Spain, England, Italy

These three European giants fluffed their lines on the big stage. Spain, winners of the last three major football tournaments, crashed out in the first week. England self-destructed as usual, earning just one point from three very listless performances. Italy, a country that some had predicted to go far in Brazil, couldn't even get out of their group. There will be a lot of soul searching in the summer as these proud footballing nations begin their preparations for the qualifying phase of the next European Championships in France in 2016.

site_title: Semi-permanent beauty
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Semi-permanent beauty

For time-strapped women, the latest in time-saving beauty treatments help cut down face- prepping considerably. But are some of the treatments worth the risks? By May Yip

Published Fri, Jul 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

FORGET the five-minute face. Recent research by US morning TV programme The Today Show and mass media corporation AOL found that the average woman spends 55 minutes on her appearance every day - or two weeks in a year.

But if a similar study were to be made on women here, those numbers may take a big dip. Today, minutes could be shaved off one's beauty routine thanks to a slew of lasting beauty treatments - from hair straightening sessions that don't leave tresses looking totally limp, to natural-looking brows that mimic Cara Delevingne's voluminous arches.

Homegrown semi-permanent make-up chain Erabelle has seen a 24 per cent increase in annual revenue from its eyebrow embroidery packages last year; while Strip, another local beauty chain initially known for its waxing services, notes that over 70 per cent of customers now opt for permanent Intense Pulsed Light (IPL) hair removal treatments. Half the customers at nail salon chain Manicurious also choose gel manicures over regular polishes. The earlier procedure lasts an average of two to three weeks, compared to mere days for old-school manis.

"Such spikes (in eyebrow embroidery) could well be attributed to the fact that more people realise how well-groomed brows can make a great difference to their appearance," says general manager and founder of Erabelle, Esther Kerk. "Unkempt brows can easily downplay one's tidiness. And such a procedure makes it convenient for clients to look fresh from the moment they wake up in the morning, without spending additional time trying to balance their eyebrows or groom them."

State-of-the-art brows

Corporate finance executive Linda Lee, for example, has opted for laser hair removal and semi-permanent brow and eyeliner make-up in recent years. "It is mainly out of convenience, I am just lazy, quite simply put," says Ms Lee, who would return to the salon for touch-ups on a yearly basis.

The latest breed of lasting beauty fixes is a far cry from the damaging treatments of yore, which often yielded unsightly results. Gone are the days of blue-tinted tattooed brows, for example, or nail extensions that destroy your digits. Instead, the focus is on looking naturally accentuated without wrecking one's God-given assets. "If you are comparing the earlier generations of embroidery and now, the colour pigment quality is definitely higher, and geared towards looking natural in the skin," explains Ms Kerk.

The brow embroidery chain employs European-made machines and pigments as it claims the continent is an innovator when it comes to medical tattooing. Procedures include areola re-pigmentation for patients who have undergone mastectomy; camouflaging burns and surgical scars with flesh-coloured pigment. The current needle-based technique by the centre is said to offer greater control to its brow artists and help create subtler eyebrows, and costs from S$1,314 for four sessions, for customers who have not had eyebrow embroidery done previously. The downside: Such techniques require touch-ups every three to six months, depending on one's lifestyle and skin condition.

However, this means greater flexibility for clients. In countries such as Hong Kong, customers may opt to tweak their brows according to the seasons, trends and their hair colour, says Erabelle's spokesman. Similarly at Browhaus, a wide range of colour pigments is available to match one's tresses. Its selection of 100 per cent vegetable dyes are also safe and don't fade out into unsatisfactory hues - like a reddish undertone often associated with brown-based dyes. Technicians wield a flexible carving tool to manually create three-dimensional-looking brows, and "Brow Resurrection" services range from S$963 to S$2,140.

But while such treatments have caught up with the times, not all semi-permanent procedures are made the same. With a huge variance in pricing also comes a wide range in hygiene and safety levels. Since such treatments have long-term effects, there is also a higher level of risk involved.

Gel manicures, for example, may be the holy grail of nails but they run the gamut from hard gels to gel polishes. While "true gel" nails are cured to a hard, long-lasting finish, a hybrid variant - the gel polish, is cheaper and dries faster, but could contain noxious ingredients.

"A certain ingredient found in most gel polishes, and not gel nails, is BHA (butylated hydroxyanisole), which is considered a cancer-causing agent," says Shawn Tan, co-owner of Manicurious, which offers the more nail-friendly "true gel" brand from Japan, Presto. "So, it is recommended to pay more for a reputable gel brand rather than choosing cheaper options."

And although recent studies have noted that there is a low chance of getting skin cancer from using traditional ultra-violet (UV) lamps to dry nail polish, Presto gels are cured with LED lamps instead, which emit lower levels of UV radiation and require a shorter curing time. The nail colours from the brand are also tailored to Asian skin tones. A normal non-gel manicure costs about S$30.

"With the right manicurist and company culture, much of the damage can be prevented," explains Mr Tan, who prices his gel manicures at S$85. "Although pricier, proper gel removers are a lot less harsh than the use of pure acetone to soak off gels, and if a manicurist is not rushed into scraping off the gel overlay because of waiting customers, obviously your nails will be healthier."

Likewise, while it appears that anyone with basic motor faculties could zap away a couple of stray follicles, the criteria for picking an IPL or laser hair removal centre should go beyond a low price. In lesser hands, IPL treatments may require numerous sessions before results can be seen, cause discomfort or even result in burns, says a spokesman for Strip, which also employs FDA-approved machines proprietary to the company. Prices start from about S$80 for the removal of fuzz from one area of the face, to just under S$2,000 to treat the legs of male clients.

"All our therapists are trained to identify skin issues such as dry and dehydrated skin, inflammation, rashes, eczema and rosacea on sight, and will advise you to treat your skin condition before returning for your IPL treatment," adds the spokesman. "Even if your skin issue could not be detected by the naked eye, the therapists are trained to be able to tell if you should continue with the IPL treatment based on the feel of the applicator as it glides on your skin."

Furthermore, hygiene should be of utmost importance for the professionals executing such beauty services, and at Browhaus, work areas and tools are sterilised with hospital-grade disinfectants, and new blades and needles are used for each session to prevent cross-contamination. Always held in private treatment rooms, rather than at an eyebrow artist's home or the atrium of a shopping mall, sanitation is also better managed.

"It is not cheap to undergo laser hair removal, but I do think that these treatments are worth investing in, especially for a lazy girl like myself," admits Ms Lee.

"I have not had any bad experiences, but I do hear of stories of girls going to less established salons to get their hair removal or eyebrows done, and end up with unsightly eyebrow shapes or adverse skin reactions."

Ultimately, such procedures may appeal to slothful sorts, but one has to put in the time and effort to track down the right treatments, or else possibly live with the undesirable results.

Asia-Pac airlines close weaker

Nisha Ramchandani

Published

Fri, Jul 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

SHARES of Asia-Pacific carriers closed slightly lower yesterday after the news that Malaysia Airlines flight MH17 had gone down in war-torn eastern Ukraine.

Malaysia Airlines saw the biggest fall, shedding 2.5 sen to close at 20 sen yesterday, albeit recovering from an intra-day low of 18.5 sen. This is still above the 15.5 sen that the counter fell to on May 19 and significantly lower than the 32 sen the stock was trading at in early January.

Shares in Singapore Airlines closed one Singapore cent lower at S$10.49, while Cathay Pacific ended the day's trading at HK$14.40, down eight HK cents. Asian markets were broadly lower as the Ukraine government and pro-Russia rebels blamed each other for shooting down MH17 while Israel added to concerns by mounting a ground offensive in Gaza.

site_title: Amundi triples Asian electronic forex trading volume in 2 years
content:
SUBSCRIBERS

Amundi triples Asian electronic forex trading volume in 2 years

Published

Fri, Jul 18, 2014 · 10:00 PM

Singapore

AMUNDI Asset Management has tripled its electronic foreign-exchange trading volume in Asia over the past two years as Europe's biggest asset manager seeks to boost speed and transparency.

Amundi conducts 70 per cent of its currency transactions in the region electronically, up from 15- 20 per cent two years ago, according to David Logerais, the Singapore-based head of Asian trading. Out of all fixed-income trading, 60-65 percent is now done online, he said. Amundi oversees the equivalent of about US$1 trillion in trading globally, according to its website.

"The main advantages of electronic trading are efficiency and transparency," Mr Logerais said in a July 14 interview. "There's a lot of time and cost saved, and it annihilates risk of trading error."

Electronic transactions climbed in 2013 to about three- quarters of global foreign-exchange trading volume, according to Greenwich Associates data. At least a dozen regulators on three continents are investigating whether traders in the US$5.3 trillion-a-day market colluded with counterparts in other firms to manipulate benchmarks such as WM/Reuters rates.

WM/Reuters rates are published hourly for 160 currencies and half-hourly for the 21 most-traded and are used by money managers and pension funds to determine what they pay for foreign currency. The benchmarks are based on trades in a minute-long period starting 30 seconds before the beginning of each half-hour. The most widely used is the 4pm London fix.

Benchmark WM/Reuters rates are collected and distributed by Thomson Reuters Corp and World Markets Co, a unit of Boston-based State Street Corp. Bloomberg LP, the parent company of Bloomberg News, competes with Thomson Reuters in providing news and information as well as currency-trading systems.

"Whenever we aren't required to comply with the fixing time for executing orders, we try to avoid it so we can open the trade to competition," Amundi's Mr Logerais said. "Our top priority is to preserve the interest of our clients."

While the asset manager doesn't get a lot of requests in Asia for trades to be executed at the London fix, it is being "very sensitive" to updates from regulators on the matter, he said.

The Financial Stability Board, which is led by Bank of England governor Mark Carney and reports to the Group of 20 (G-20) nations, published this week details of plans to overhaul the process of setting benchmark currency rates.

Bloomberg News reported last month that US prosecutors have broadened their probe into currency dealing by targeting the mark-ups that the world's biggest banks may impose on some customers.

The investigations are compounding troubles for foreign-exchange traders this year, who face their biggest-ever loss as volatility fell to a record.

A Parker Global Strategies LLC index that tracks the performance of 14 top currency funds has fallen an annualised 6.4 per cent - the biggest drop in data going back to 2003. Deutsche Bank AG's Currency Volatility Index fell to an all-time low of 5.02 per cent on July 3.

Price swings in equity markets have also diminished. The Chicago Board Options Exchange Volatility Index fell 4.6 per cent to 10.32 on July 3 - the lowest close in more than seven years.

"Maintaining your profitability is the biggest concern for the industry when trading volumes drop," Mr Logerais said. "Less activity means people not being occupied on the desk, so there may be pressure to eliminate positions." Bloomberg
